description:
This review is solely for the friendliness of the staff and not for the food. 

I drove across the bridge to pick up my uncle whom i've not seen in 16 yrs and this was our meeting spot. They finished their lunch at the restaurant and asked if it was ok to wait for me there, according to my uncle, the staff was very friendly and didnt chase them out. Mind you i was driving out from the valley to the city with 2 accidents along the way.. it took me almost 2 hrs to get there with a stop in between to get my parents.. long story short, i finally got to the restaurant, said Hello to my uncle & aunt outside then off to find restroom.. lol
I walked in anticipating some resistance from wait staff giving me a hard time about restrooms for patrons only but NOPE, they said YES, go ahead its in the back and pointed me to it.. I was So relieved and genuinely appreciative of their understanding... So to repay that gesture, here is a 5 star review for their kindness.... And will try their food next time i'm in the city.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Great spot in Inner Richmond. 

Dongbei food is Northeast China food and similar to Shanghai food but still different. Most popular Dongbei dishes are usually the dumplings and the beef wraps. 

I have been looking for a great DongBei style cuisine for a while now. My favorite place is actually a place in Taipei of all places since I haven't had the chance to visit Northeastern China yet. 

Usually I would get a few types of dumplings, the hot and sour soup, a vegetable dish, and the beef wrap. 

This place is very affordable for what you get and the portions are large. What I love about SF is the ability to get food from several regions of China and Dongbei Mama fills a niche in the palette. 

It's quite good for what it is, and if you stick with the popular dishes from other Yelpers, you are going to be fine. Dumplings are always great, soup is always great, so get those and then try some other random dish if you feel daring.
author: James N.

description:
Came here for lunch as I felt like eating Shanghai Soup Dumplings aka Xiao Long Bao.

The food came out rather quickly but was a bit hard to flag our waiter down as he wasn't paying much attention. I was also constantly swatting little fruit flies as they attempted to land on our food and plates..... 

The Xiao Long Bao looked beautiful but would loved more soup and more salt in the filling; otherwise it was just okay. 

Their beef pancake was like eating a banhmi, which isn't a bad thing. The scallion pancake was just crisp enough with beef and fresh vegetables as the filling. 

We also had their slightly sweet and sour eggplant stir fry, which was quite good (unpictured). 

We did leave quite abruptly as we were tired of shooing the fruit flies. In any the food was alright and portions are filling.
author: Alex C.

description:
Authentic, classic and cheap Chinese and Taiwanese food. Make sure to get the Sliced Beef Pancake! Cut into 5 sizable portions, it came with plenty of green onions, cucumber, and hoisin sauce to balance the more savory pancake. 

The xiao long bao (Taiwanese soup dumplings) was great, and came with 9 pieces and black vinegar on the side. We also ordered the dan dan noodles, which they made with szechuan chili oil, minced pork, onion, and a few pieces of bok choy. Disproportionate amount of noodle to everything else, wouldn't really recommend.

Owners were super friendly and accommodating, even letting us take the tea to go (a friend had a cough and wanted it, lol).
author: Rachel L.

description:
Came in for late lunch and found that the menu is huge and so are the portions. We Loved the salt and pepper tofu -our favorite dish. Service adequate- order by number as our waiter confused our order. We also had a pretty ordinary dish of garlic spinach with a tasty enormous Beef filled pancake!- sort of a Chinese  type sandwich.
They kindly boxed our leftovers to take home. Will bring a larger party next time!
author: Helen M.

description: Classic hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant: extremely affordable and fulfills your innermost Chinese food cravings. Really sweet staff and delicious food. I recommend ordering the plates to share. If you're ever in the area craving some authentic Chinese food, Dong Bri Mama is the place to hit up!
author: Karoline A.

description:
First review from my food trip in SF! Landed at night and went straight to Dong Bei Mama for dinner. It was fantastic and I definitely recommend going here if you want some authentic Chinese aFood. They offer a large array of regional Chinese dishes from Sichuan to Cantonese cuisine. Though there is a lot on the menu, try to go out of the box with the things you order (ex. NOT the orange chicken or King Pao Beef). 

Service was really friendly and attentive. Definitely come here with your friends and family so you can share the dishes! The dishes i ordered can definitely be split among 2-3 people. 

WHAT I ORDERED: 
1) Beef Roll Pancake ($7.89): Definitely a winner and my favorite thing I ordered! Features a warm crispy flaky chewy scallion pancake that encloses fresh cucumber and cilantro with a hoisin-marinated melt-in-the-mouth beef. This thing is huge and is as long as my fore arm!

2) Honey Walnut Shrimp ($13.98): Nice crunch to the honey walnut shrimp due to the crispy and light batter. One of my qualms with this dish is sometimes the shrimp is 80% batter but it's not the case with this at all! Walnuts are deliciously candied.

3) I also ordered stir fried vegetables with pork. It was yummy but almost too oily. Still would recommend, I just would pair it up with something lighter.
author: Julie D.

description:
We've always passed by Dong Bei Mama but always wrote it off for 2 reasons: 1. The majority of their clients are from Chinese tour buses and 2. Their name in Chinese is very odd (according to my parents). But then it gets featured in the Chronicle as a restaurant that best represents it's region of China in the Bay Area...

...whaaaat?!

And so we came. Twice. In a week. Because our first time was good enough to warrant a second try of their menu. Be forewarned, the portion sizes here are huuuuuge. 

Our favorites to date:

1. Beef roll pancake - there's a place on Taraval that makes these amazing beef roll pancakes and then you come here and feel like that place has been ripping you off 10 fold because this one is truly a giant. The fresh cilantro and cucumbers are a refreshing contrast between the thin sliced beef, hoisin sauce, and the wrap itself which may be considered a little thick.

2. Steamed tofu and fish. It's delivery is a long block of soft tofu topped with fish filets that's been steamed together and garnished with sweet soy sauce, oil, and scallions. Truly delicious in my opinion.

3. Dried tofu sauteed with chives. Very simple dish in my opinion, but executed well. Chives had a nice sweet crunch to them without being too strong.

4. Pork belly rice. Huge portions. Plus a very generous helping of braised pork belly that is melt in your mouth decadent. The crunch from the bell peppers and sauteed onions are the only things that bring you back to reality.

Overall, service can definitely be a hit or miss. One waitress definitely knows her stuff though making key recommendations and also turning us away from dishes that she wouldn't recommend. Maybe some people would find that pushy, but all of her suggestions seemed spot on.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
I had a difficult time here due to the language barrier. When I first walked in, I was acknowledged, but stood there a little awkwardly waiting to get seated. I ordered the Soup Dumplings, Honey Walnut Shrimp, and Dan Dan noodles. 

The server didn't write down my order but I didn't think she would need to because we ordered only three things. The Dan Dan noodles came out first which was a little bland for my liking. There wasn't much flavor to it which was a shame because it smelled delicious. The server then brought out some sort of stew that I didn't order. I explained to him that I ordered the soup dumpling (xaio long bao) and he didn't know how to respond so he just stared. The lady who took my order came out and said that I ordered the stew, which I didn't, then she said "if you want the xaio long bao you have to wait" so we waited. When the xaio long bao came out I was so excited because it looked really authentic! It came with 8 pieces, but I was really disappointed because there were only two that actually had soup in them (which I didn't get to try). The meat inside had really good flavors, though. The honey *pecan* shrimp was really good. The shrimp was crispy and the sauce wasn't too sweet or creamy. The presentation was cute too! 

Aside from the experience I had with the language barrier, I was pretty unhappy with soup dumplings with no soup in it. Don't let my review stop you from trying this place! The reviews were very good.
author: Tammy L.

description:
Yay beef roll pancake!! Yay beef noodle soup (spicy), and yay for the roast duck!

We ordered way too much food for 2, finished the soup and took the beef roll pancake and the duck home. 

Beef roll heated up fine on the stove! Mmmm I will definitely be back!
author: Mandi W.

description:
We came on a rainy weekday for dinner, and from first sight, the restaurant didn't look like it would be a very authentic, Chinese-food, experience. The restaurant wasn't very modern looking, and it wasn't the cleanest environment either. 

We ordered the chicken and mushroom stew and their beef pancake roll, and both were good! The chicken and mushroom stew was warm and hearty, and I loved the soup that the stew was made in. The chicken had too many bones for my taste, so eating the meat was pretty difficult. The beef pancake was good, but I do wish there were less raw green onions. 

Overall, a decent place for chinese food if you're in the area!
author: Sandra S.

description: The dishes were served quickly but not in good taste. We ordered sautéed crispy fried pork and 疙瘩汤 (dough drops in three seafood delicacies soup), where the dough drops are huge as dice and the seafood inside is not fresh.
author: 欣羽

description:
I had a wonderfully enjoyable experience here. We were waiting on people but they were extremely patient with us. The restaurant is big, but it fills up fast and the tables can feel a little cramped. The service was obscurely fast. They pump out the food super quick and it's piping hot.

I recommend the Beef Pancake - I could eat an entire one to myself and it's enormous. Great to share with friends if you feel like sharing. The pancake is so crispy which I love. The Fish in Chili Oil was very flavorful and had a wonderful kick in the face and tongue. It goes great with rice! Spicy Eggplant was good as is the Mapu Tofu. There was something very comforting about the Sour Cabbage and Pork Belly Soup. Lots of rich pork flavor contrasted by the welcomed taste of the mildly acidic and slightly firm cabbage.

Unfortunately, I would advise against getting the Hot and Sour Soup. That's a staple for me, but this place serves it mostly hot temperature and spicy wise. It wasn't enjoyable, and the acidity made it almost more like a punishment. I couldn't recommend the Vegetarian Dumplings even if you're a vegetarian. They use mushrooms and glass noodles, which is normally fine, but the taste was kind of cardboard or cupboard - very old tasting.

We came here early so it was pretty slow, but then it got PACKED from a bunch of tour buses and the turnover was SO HIGH. This place is something else, definitely recommended to everyone who loves this kind of Chinese food.
author: Corey P.

description:
Food: 4/5
Service: 3.5/5
Ambiance: 3/5
Overall:  One of the better Chinese spots in the city.  
 
The extended review...
 
Food:
Beef Pancake Roll - Yummy yummy.  Crispy on the outside and filled with beef and scallions.
 
Snow Pea Shoots - You can never go wrong with this dish no matter where you go.  The texture of this veggie dish is very fresh and crisp.
 
Dan Dan Mein (Spicy Noodles) - BEWARE OF THE CHILI OIL.  It'll burn going in and burn going out.  It's definitely one of the staples for the Szechuan province and it's usually a must.  Can't say no to noodles.
 
Fish and Tofu - Very fresh and melt in your mouth dish.  Very light and tasty.
 
Service:  For a Chinese joint it's not too bad with service.  Not service with a smile but it's efficient and attentive.
 
Ambiance:  Just your average Chinese joint.  Not exactly hole in the wall but it's a hair better.
author: Spencer Q.

description: Came here because another restaurant we were trying to go to had a very long wait, and I was very underwhelmed by the food. We ordered the green beans, duck, and chow mein, and out of the three the green beans were by far the best. We barely touched the other two dishes, and didn't get a to go box. I am asian, so I do have a higher standard, but Dong Bei Mama really fell short from my expectations.
author: Ross S.

description:
Delicious  

We ordered half duck  and pork buns. 
My daughter ordered combo fried rice and pot stickers. 
We ordered garlic spinach and everything was fantastic. 

The portions are big and the three of us ate way to much.  All because of how tasty everything was.  
Complimentary tea was served as well. 

All for $60 out the door. 

Spinach was Chinese water spinach in a delicate garlic sauce.  Not potent.  Just savory. 
The duck was crispy and fatty. Great flavor. Cut in just the right size. Plenty for 2 ppl. 

Potstickers we delicious and served crispy and hot. Comes with a black vinaigrette of some kind. 12 pcs. 

The pork buns we like dim sum. Steamed and soft.  Great pork flavor and came with 8 pcs. 
The fried rice was a combo and had plenty of shrimp and beef and vegetables. Just the right amount of food for three people over all.  

I'd definitely recommend this place for all to try.
author: Rocky S.

description: It will take a few more visits to get this one down.  The menu is diverse and extensive with considerable and less usual items,.  All means you can't really judge this one-off.  I wasn't crazy about the beef pancake, but if I needed something good and filling to eat while driving this is a long way better than a big mac.  Somehow that doesn't do it justice; maybe I just wanted less pancake.  Steamed fish fillet with tofu, check.  Shredded pig ear appetizer was good, crunchy, spicy.  Pig's blood, beef and tripe in chili soup is a lot better than it may sound but could I added more chili.  All in all, this was more than enough for me to plan a return.  Just have to figure a time when there isn't a busload of Chinese tourists which seem to arrive hourly, though this in itself is actually a positive indication.
author: Bob S.

description: This is the place to be for cheap meals with huge portions! This Chinese food joint has a wide selections of foods, but they're known for the beef pancake (pictured below)! We also got the bok choy with mushrooms! The Xiao long Bao, aka soup dumplings, were pretty good too! I think there were 8 dumpling and it was pretty filling. The only downside to this place is that it's kind of hard to flag a waiter down sometimes. But the huge portion size and low prices completely make up for it!
author: Caitlyn S.

description: Giving this place all the stars because their service is wonderful--attentive (refilled our tea 3 times before we were done) and friendly. Also their beef pancake is a magnificent beast.
author: Cheryl K.

description:
We came in on a chilly Monday night. They sat us by the door even though the majority of the tables were empty, which was disappointing. We were able to pretty quickly order Hot and Sour Soup, Soup Dumplings (XLB), Chow Mein, and Mongolian Beef. The food was brought out quickly, but in reverse order from what I would normally expect. First they brought the Chow Mein and Mongolian Beef, and then the soup, followed by dumplings (much later).

We enjoyed the chow mein- it was very straightforward, no frills, but a nice dish. The Mongolian Beef was pretty good as well, but very basic. The Soup was good at first, but the huge chunk of cilantro that they threw on top totally altered the flavor of the soup until it was overwhelmingly cilantro. Even my boyfriend who LOVES cilantro thought it was too much. I hate cilantro, so it was disappointing. 

Then they brought out some sort of dumplings; definitely not the dumplings we had ordered. Only one of the servers spoke english, so we had to track her down to let her know that these were not the soup dumplings we had ordered. She was super nice and said she would bring us the right ones. However, it took another 15 minutes or so until they arrived, so we had been finished eating for quite some time. On top of that, the dumplings were just okay, not great (and I eat a ton of XLB). They were quite bland and the meatball in the middle was very large and dense. However, the worst part was the final dumpling (my last bite of the meal). I took in the whole dumpling, and basically bit into cold grizzle. The meatball was a completely different color from the others and it was disgusting. I was pretty bummed that eating that dumpling (and then spitting it out) was my last taste. I cannot recommend these XLB.

Overall, I added an extra star for the quality service from the one waitress we encountered. She was adorable and very attentive. The food is very generic Chinese. There's nothing special about it, but it's not bad.
author: Hannah S.

description:
Many restaurants have one signature dish that keeps them staying in business and it's definitely the spicy beef noodle soup here for me. Although they have a wide ranging menu, the other items didn't really stand out as I was hoping.

I actually wanted to come here because the beef roll pancake looked so delicious.  The verdict? I've had better for cheaper. The pancake is stuffed with cucumbers and the beef inside was too sweet for my tastes buds.  But luckily the noodles saved the day and my dinner.  Let's critique the broth; spicy, savory, and numbing from the peppers.  Noodles had great chew and I'm not sure if they made fresh or bought it. There could have been some more beef but considering how cheap it was, I didn't mind. Another dish I tried were the spicy chicken.  I would skip this since the chicken was cut up into pieces so small I thought they were scrap pieces at first. 

It's run by Chinese folks so don't expect the best customer service. The gentleman bringing out the noodles as spilled some of it on our table and walked away without offering napkins or helping wipe it off! C'mon man, we both know you saw it!
author: Quoc N.

description:
So delicious and huge portions! There's an amazing variety of items on the menu, from spicy Szechuan food to pretty decent handmade dumplings. We ordered the spicy stewed fish, eggplant vegetable dish, and boiled pork dumplings. All of it was delicious, and I would definitely go back to try the other items on the menu.

Service was also great - the waiter was more attentive than the average Chinese restaurant and didn't mind at all that we stayed after closing.
author: Hali M.

description:
This review is based on one dish - Tossed Mung Bean Clear Noodles with Homemade Sauce ($12.99). Listed under cold appetizer dishes. WARNING: normally comes with multiple meats and egg. If you are vegetarian, you have to ask for no meat. The lovely server said that would be fine. But then, when it came out, it still had ham. It's pretty easy to see it because the dish comes arranged with the ingredients arrayed in a pretty circle with the clear noodles in a pile in the middle. As I was trying to ask if the pink stuff was ham, the first server realized the issue and whisked it away. When the dish came out a minute later, it was a little less pretty so they may have just pulled off the ham, or been in a rush to replace the dish. If you are a strict vegetarian, please be careful.  They were not busy, I was one of 2 tables at the time.  Dropped a star for the meat being included. 

The dish is tasty, good amount of both chili and numbing pepper, and rich with sesame paste. Would have liked a little more julienned vegetables to balance the sauce and to get some veggies with each bite. The noodles are very springy and smooth and I enjoyed the contrast with the fresh veggies.  Generous serving, would be great as a shared dish.
author: Eri S.

description:
Beef rolls! 
Beeeef Rooooolllsssss!
This is my go to spot for beef rolls. They are massive, delicious, and one of my top 20 ultimate comfort foods. 
The worst thing is I never know if I should drink beer or whiskey with them rolls.
author: Jonathan Y.

description:
Great food and great value for the price (huge portions!!). $115 pre-tax for a HUGE meal fit for 12. Unheard of.

Got 10 dishes and everything was pretty good - but VERY oily.
Service is quick and attentive, restaurant was fairly clean.

The only criticism I have is for the menu - it's a bit confusing because the first few pages are broken out by 'family style entree' or by 'cuisine' which includes various veggie/meat ingredient dishes, but the last few pages are broken out by ingredient type (veggie / meat / noodle/rice) - so when looking for a specific veggie dish, for example, I didn't realize there were ADDITIONAL veggie dishes that were not under the veggie' category as it was lumped under 'family entree' category.

Favorites for me:
- Zha jiang mian - good Chinese black bean sauce flavor - savory & flavorful - enough sauce to coat all of the noodles 
- Salt & pepper fried fish - mmmm if you like salt & pepper fried anything, you will like this. Sooo savory & yummy
- House special eggplant - VERY oily but sooo delicious. Subtle sweet & sour sauce but acts as a perfect complement with the tender & savory fried eggplant
- Sizzling lamb platter - HUGE portion and lamb was very tender, not too gamey or saucey.

Favorites for others at my table:
- Potstickers - juicy and looked nicely fried but not enough crisp on the skin for me to rate it higher, though $9 for 12 dumplings is a great price and the potstickers were still decent
- Spicy fish (forgot which one lol, there are a few on the menu..) - good & tender fish, no complaints!
- Beef pancake - favorite dish of my bro & wife but too doughy and not enough beef/sauce for me, at least

I will DEF return again!
author: Emily C.

description:
I'll start by saying this place get packed with tourists every 30 minutes, so they may take a while to get your food. 

Very casual and authentic Chinese restaurant. Only one waitress spoke English, very nice lady. 
The XLB was very good, nice flavor, delicious soup and the meat was tender. 
The beef roll/pancake was very crispy, lots of thinly sliced beef shank and tendon with lots of green onions and cilantro! Sooo good. Also got the thinly sliced beef with chili oil, not bad but I've had better (in SoCal). 
Lastly, the beef/tendon spicy soup. This dish was OK, probably will not order again. The noodles were fair, I like my noodles to be a bit more firm and chewy. The soup is very numbing. So if you like that feeling, drink it! 

Overall, good food. I'll try some other dishes next time but will definitely get the Beef Pancake again!
author: Susan L.

description: Went there for lunch because hong kong lounge II was closed and this place had some good reviews. Its a trap. The smell was really bad walking in and the food was just mediocre.
author: Simon R.

description:
This restaurant is great! A true diamond in the rough. My dad has been coming here for years (but never took me, ok dad).

My first experience we ordered the bacon dish, tofu chow fun and the assorted seafood soup. Portions are huge. Waiter is super nice and cute. 

The only warning I give of this restaurant is to it can get extremely crowded with tour bus groups. On the plus side these groups literally come in, eat and leave within 20 minutes. Everything is ready to roll when they arrive and they leave happy and full. 

I'll be back!
author: Shannon M.

description:
What an awesome place for its price! I went here with a group of 7 other people and the bill came out to be about $11 a person, including tax and tip. What a deal, especially in the city of San Francisco!

We ordered a variety of dishes: the beef pancakes (2 orders), a fish stew, pork and cabbage, eggplant, steamed fish... I can't remember the exact names of the dishes, but honestly -- all were so good, and probably the most authentic Chinese food I've had so far in the city. I don't think you can go wrong with anything.

Tip: go with a group of friends and order a lot!
author: Julianna K.

description:
Overall not a bad place. We came because a family friend was in town and I had a party nearby afterwards, so I just needed a Chinese restaurant in the Richmond. The food was fine, didn't blow us away but worked. 

Yelp had some health violation warning when we opened this restaurant's page on our mobile app, but as far as we could tell, no one had any issues.

RESERVATIONS: Made for six people on a Saturday at 7pm over the phone, with just a few day's notice. They didn't have a wait but were busy - the reservation was a good idea for a group of our size.

SERVICE: Fine, nothing to complain about!

THE FOOD: We got tons of dishes, these are the ones I remember.
* Pork belly - 3.5 stars
Good flavor, but the meat is quite fatty! Might not be for everyoen.

* Beef pancake - 4 stars
Their signature dish - very unique, and a very filling dish!

* Stir fried potato strips (not sure what it's called in English) - 3 stars
This was quite oily and a bit light on flavor.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
This place is a favorite place to grab really authentic Chinese food in the Richmond. I've been quite a few times for dinner and lunch. It's usually pretty empty, and waiters are no nonsense, just take your order, get you your food and your check (which is perfectly fine by me!)

We got half a smoked/roast duck once. It was definitely... smoky tasting, and quite dry, not juicy and fatty like Peking duck is. 

The pork stew with white gourd is my favorite thing on the menu. It is very home-y, something a Chinese mother would cook. It has pieces of pork ribs, with winter melon squash and clear, flat noodles in a delicious, light broth. 

Their sizzling lamb platter is also quite good. You get a good amount of delicious, juicy (and pretty fatty) pieces of lamb, spiced with cumin with thin cut onions. 

Their zha jiang mian was not good at all. The noodle quality was not good, and topped with large pieces of cut peppers, and just overall, not authentic. 

Their cold dish appetizers: we've gotten pork ears and "delicious chicken" are all tasty, and soaked in chili hot oil, though I found the chicken really dry.
author: Ke C.

description:
I highly recommend giving this place a try! 

We didn't know where to go in the city so we just started walking around and stumbled onto this gem. Let me say the food is DELICIOUS. Everything we ordered was full in flavor, fresh, and just what we wanted. The portions were huge!! The small hot and sour soup was big enough to feed 10 people! Everything was brought out in under ten minutes. Very fast,  friendly service. All at an extremely affordable price. We will be returning.
author: R G.

description:
I dig it! I usually go to my typical spot for Chinese pancakes. However, my other half and I wanted to try a new restaurant and we're so glad we did!

If there is any dish that is a "must-order", I must say that the beef pancake is the way to go. It's amazingly tasty and packed with multi-dimensions of textures.  You get the crunchiness from the fried scallion pancake, the freshness from cilantro, and the smooth texture from the thinly sliced beef. Not only is the beef pancake tasty, it's also as long as my forearm! Talk about some great bang for your buck!
author: Briana H.

description: This place was a pleasant surprise. Definitely a hole in the wall type of place but much to my surprise the food was very tasty and not overly greasy. The beef pancake was the most surprising. When they brought it out I thought I would avoid it, but I decided to take a chance and it wasn't greasy at all and the filling was quite light and fresh tasting. Definitely a place I'll preference in the future when I want easy Chinese food.
author: Justin S.

description:
Came here with my family after a long day. Food here really hit the spot! I saw the prices on the menu and they looked higher than my normal price point, but when they came out with the dishes, I understood why; the plates were huge! We ordered:

Picked cabbage with vermicelli soup
- delicious! It's the kind of soup that warms the soul. Has a slight gingery/spicy taste that'll warm you from the inside out 
Signature sliced beef pancake
- the pancake was thicker than I was used to, but I wasn't mad about it. Very filling 
Steamed fish filet with tofu in chili sauce
- the sauce was spicy! Crunchy from the celery too. It also had a layer of spam/ham. Delicious
Signature eggplant with homemade sauce
- the way they cut this eggplant was unique, such that if you tried to grab it, you'd get a lot of skin which is not a bad deal since they fried it well. Each bite was tasty!

Order rice and you'll have a well balanced meal (not too oily). I took all the leftovers home and it lasted me 4 more meals! Worth!
author: Serena W.

description: One of the best Chinese restaurants in the city I've been to. The portions were great. The scallion pancake was so crispy and fluffy just like how my grandma made it when I was little. Love the minced pork over rice too. Will definitely come back and try other stuff!
author: Doreen D.

description:
Took my family here on a Sunday around noon for lunch. My dad loves beef noodle soup, so I thought we would give this place a try! Parking wasn't terrible, we found a meter spot across the street. The restaurant was half filled, so we were seated right away. Typical Chinese restaurant, not the cleanest furniture, but nothing raised any concerns. We ordered a bunch of dishes to share. The beef noodle soup was just ok. I wasn't really a fan of the thick cut noodles they used. The broth was flavorful, yet not too salty. I hate having to chug a whole glass of water after drinking soup at some places. I really liked the dandan noodles, spicy minced pork over noodles. They use the same thick cut noodles, which in my opinion taste better with sauce instead of soup. We were able to adjust the spicy level, which is a plus since my dad can't really handle spicy (those Cantonese genes haha). The beef pancake roll was pretty good! The pancake was crispy and the beef and veggies inside worked well together. We also got the xiao long baos, but nothing really stood out about them. 

The food is a solid 3 but their service is amazing! Our waitress was super friendly and attentive. My brother accidentally dropped his chopsticks, and by the time he picked it up from the floor, the waitress already walked over to our table and had a new set ready. The price of everything was also super affordable. Most of our dishes were around $8!!! I'll definitely drop by again to try the other items on their menu (they also have exquisite Chinese delicacies such as pig ears, pig head, etc.) Overall, it's not the best Chinese food I've had but considering the great service and low prices ... it's a 4 star for me!
author: Nancy C.

description:
18.03.31              of many visits


Food -------------------  4 thru 4.5
Service ----- cooking 4.5 - speed from order to table
            table service 3.5 thru 4 


Sauteed beef
    Sauteed super tender beef w 
    soft slivers of onions that infused the fragarent onion 

Smoked Pork Belly w green beans
    Yes the pork have a nice non overwhelming smoky taste!
    Simple green beans

Clam w Black Bean Sauce
   Basic black bean calms

Spicy Chicken chunks
   WARNING ... even when we requested mild ... 
       those seeds are killer ... remove it to downgrade the burn
   A nice ... cumin? or something flavor to it.


Rolled Beef Pancake
   Slices of marinated beef
   Slivers of cucumber
   Nicely pan fried crunchy sheet of dough to add texture

Steamed Vegetable Dumplings
   Nice portion and tasty
   Comes with a vinegar for dipping
author: S.K. Y.

description:
In terms of Chinese food, this place is a diamond in the rough. I'm used to the South Bay which is full of pretentious, expensive Chinese restaurants (with a few notable exceptions). This place is the opposite: it is affordable, the food tastes extremely authentic (and to be clear, it is very hard to find Dong Bei food in the Bay Area. Dong Bei means northeastern chinese food, which is an uncommon type of cuisine amongst the usual offerings like Sichuanese or Cantonese food). 

We had all the specialty dishes that they offered (I am going off the chinese names here, so forgive me if they don't align with the English names on their menu): Beef Pancake Roll, Stir Fried Potato Slices, Sour Vegetable Soup with Lamb, Guo Bao Rou (thin slices of pork breaded with a crispy sweet outer layer). I'm sure I missed something here, but it wouldn't be hard for you to figure out which dishes are the specialty here. 

Again, I was incredibly surprised by the quality and the portion size at Dong Bei Mama. The mama herself is a very sweet lady who will take care of your party. I am more than willing to come back here the next time I am in SF!
author: Bryce L.

description:
Hella good. Just be aware that the place experiences huge surges in customers due to the tour buses taking a lot of groups here.

Recommended:

Sour Cabbage and Pork Belly Soup: Clean, not overly sour, delicious. Couldn't stop eating it.

Beef Pancake: Not usually a big fan of this dish but this place makes it exceptionally well. The flavors are balanced and it's huge but not overly greasy.

Fish in Chili Oil: Well seasoned and the fish was cooked just right.

Don't tell your friends about this place because I want to enjoy it some more before the lines get worse!
author: Brandon W.

description:
I've been here twice, and both times it was a whirlwind of dishes since I came with larger groups of people, which was ideal to eat family style and sample more of their dishes.

A few highlights:

Beef pancake: think of scallion pancake (doughy on the inside, lightly crispy on the outside), except it's now a beef sandwich. Inside is a sweet soy bean based sauce w slices of beef, cucumber, and cilantro (I prefer that removed), that together creates this delicious asian sandwich.

Salt and pepper fried tofu: the texture of these little cubes were a pleasant surprise. The fried outer skin is thin and each bite is airy and light.

Spicy white fish (I have no idea what the actual name of this dish is): in summation, it's white steamed fish in a red spicy sauce that goes swimmingly w white rice.

Cold potato strips: the Chinese take on potato makes the starch less overwhelming. It's cut up into little strips, stir fried w bell peppers, and served chilled.

Come here for great food and relaxed ambiance. They can accommodate large parties.
author: Cici T.

description: Mapo tofu was excellent and went really well with rice. Xiao Long Bao definitely  seemed like it had been frozen and in sufficiently heated, as some meat pieces were more dry and rough than others, and there was no soup in any of them. Vegetable dumplings were quite good and tasted homemade. Beef chow fun was okay, but the beef pieces were a little hard to chew. Overall, we would come back for the mapo tofu and try out other dishes.
author: Lucy T.

description:
Solid Chinese food in Inner Richmond.

We were a bit skeptical because the restaurant was pretty empty when we walked in during dinnertime, but the dishes spoke for themselves. The lamb ribs, sour cabbage and pork belly soup and beef scallion pancake were all very good, and portions were more than generous. 

I really enjoyed trying out ba si, a Dongbei dish consisting of fried sweet potato covered in sticky sugar syrup. They give you a bowl of ice water to dip the hot sweet potato, which causes the sugar syrup to harden into thin little strings. It's a pretty unique dessert, and I'd recommend getting it just for the experience.
author: Harry X.

description:
Dumplings, dumplings, dumplings!
Giant beef roll pancake (biggest i've ever seen)
Steamed fish and tofu.

Super authentic northern style chinese.  A chinese tour bus even pulled up and brought 40 people who seemed very happy with the food.
author: S F.

description:
First time here, was much better than I expected.

We ordered egg noodle soup
This dish was ok, not as good as I expected 
Very watery and tasty blend. 

Thick sesame pan cake
This is really good

Shred Photo dish was very good. 
Not too spicy and salty, just right. 

Over all it was good. Will be back to try other dishes.
author: Mack A.

description:
If you want excellent Chinese food that actually tastes like something you'd eat at home, this is it. Best to come with a larger group so you can try many dishes, as the dishes are family style. Averages out to $15 a person with tax and tip! Great value for great price.

PS definitely try their stews and the beef onion pancake. Those are some of their best dishes
author: Andrew L.

description:
My wife is from Heilongjiang, one of the "Dongbei" provinces. We lived together in Beijing for 3 years were we regularly ate at Dongbei-style restaurants. Dongbei cuisine is one of the "8 great chinese cuisine". What you can expect is great stews and super large portions for a cheap price. We got just that in this really authentic restaurant.

The staff was great. Facts : 
- everything we ordered was served in less than 10'
- people next to us complained that the food was too spicy and they changed their plates right away.

The food was great too. There could be minor improvements but we were deeply satisfied anyway.
We ordered 
- Dongbei luandun : the flavor was great. The braised pork should be braised longer and its skin was a bit thick. Nevertheless it was the most comforting dish on the table. Try it out on a cold day for an even stronger effect.
- Congyoubing : an onion pancake. Right on point.
- Gongbao jiding : spicy chicken with peanuts. Peanuts were too soft, the rest was perfect. I really enjoyed this version of my favorite chinese food.
- Shuizhuyu : spicy boiled fish. Was perfect for our taste.


Side notes : 

Yes it's going to be a bit greasy and oily. That's the way it's done there, were people have to go through freezing winters.

I read some people complain about dishes which are not from Dongbei.
If you go to a Sichuan (spicy food from west China) restaurant in Beijing it isn't going to be the same as Sichuan, and that's normal. 
I personally believe the way they made the shuizuyu (boiled fish) or gongbao jiding (kungpao chicken) which are both from Sichuan is more accessible to "westerners" than the Sichuan super-spicy stuff. 
Hence we felt the Sichuan dishes we ordered were great even though it might disappoint someone who experienced them in Sichuan.
If you are an expert stick with Dongbei dishes at a Dongbei restaurant.
author: Olivier T.

description:
Poor quality food. The waitress suggested wings which were tiny and frankly, pretty gross. All the vegetables we ate didn't taste fresh. Only solid dish was the beef wrapped in pastry.

Only saving grace is that it was absurdly inexpensive.
author: Nathan M.

description: Idk why this place has such a high rating. It's straight shit. When I say shit it means that the wok fish tasted like dish soap, the beef was way too chewy, and the chow mein should have just been a bottle of oil. Also the people who work here set up a row of chairs behind a table and was sleeping while we were here. I get being tired and all but be professional.
author: Sarah B.

description: This restaurant is really nice that taste is very good. As well, the fried rice is also nice. I super enjoy it. When you eat in the restaurant you feel it is really dongbei' taste.
author: Xiao M.

description:
TLDR - Known for its beef rolls, but somewhat disappointing. Overall pretty average Chinese food

I came with my family for a late 1:30PM lunch on the weekend. Still somewhat busy at that time but no wait. Plenty of parking around. The restaurant is a pretty standard Chinese restaurant. Big menu with both Chinese and English, as well as pictures for their more popular dishes, which was really helpful because I personally found their menu to be overwhelming with options.

I mostly came just for the beef pancakes so I let my parents order everything else. Our group of 4 shared an appetizer, the beef pancakes, a stew, a veggie dish and a meat dish and found that to be plenty.

Overall, decent Chinese food. Again, there's a lot on the menu so you aren't limited to one specific region of food. I didn't find anything to be particularly special and was sadly disappointed by the Yelp-loved beef pancakes.

* 003 CHINESE BATH CHAP ($7.89) - 3/5
11 slices of fatty pork cheek. Pretty typical Chinese cold appetizer

* 030 EGGPLANT WITH HOMEMADE SAUCE ($11.89) - 2/5
Meh. I should've known anything with "homemade sauce" in its name would be something doused in sauce. My parents ordered this and were disappointed as well. The sauce was very thick and overly sweet. The eggplant was surprisingly hard to eat too because the skin was tough rather than tender. 

* 046 STEWED CHICKEN WITH MUSHROOM ($11.89) - 4/5
Nothing super special about this dish but I thought it was still well executed and I enjoyed it the most out of everything we ordered. The chicken was very tender and lean, and the stew overall was very light. 

* 083 DUCKS NECK WITH CHILI SAUCE ($9.89) - 3/5
Dad ordered this because it's something familiar from his hometown. He enjoyed it but I wasn't that big of a fan. Duck neck meat is pretty lean but this dish is fried so it's a little greasy. There also isn't much meat on neck to begin with so it's really more fried bits than anything else. Flavor was good though - salty and a little numbing spicy but not too much so. 

* 151 SLICED BEEF PANCAKES ($7.89) - 3.5/5
I came for these pancakes and unfortunately was a little disappointed. The pancake was a huge portion of 6 slices just as expected. What I wasn't expecting was the pancake to be crunchy and fried on the outside, which was very different from the beef pancake rolls I'm used to. It gave it some more texture contrast but made it greasier. The filling to pancake ratio could've been better too. I would've liked either more beef/cucumber and sauce or a thinner, less chewy pancake.
author: Jessie L.

description: Went here a couple weeks ago. Solid Chinese food! Ask the waiter for advice on what to order since very restaurant has its strengths and weaknesses. We were delighted.
author: Brent C.

description:
Strange tasting food coupled with unsanitary conditions lands Dong a one star and a warning to anyone considering a meal from this restaurant.

We ordered 5 dishes and shared all. 

The beef in two of the dishes was so chewy that I had to discreetly spit it out.

The fried tofu - tasted like the oil was old / stale.

The chicken was virtually non existent in the battered encasing... 

About halfway through the meal, the tiny flies arrived, perhaps they came in from an open unscreened window above the front door... Duh...

Then on the way to the bathroom, you can see the roaches in the kitchen. Apparently they have been cited for unsanitary conditions but they claim they were corrected. Not.

I came home and took charcoal, as my stomach was aching badly.
author: Bulldog W.

description:
Food was solid. Not the best Chinese food I've had but it was alright. Close to where I live, quick staff and not crowded on a weekday for lunch. 

Ordered the beef pancake roll, beef noodle soup and soup dumplings. My mom really enjoyed the beef noodle soup. The soup dumpling was average. Not mind blowing amazing but good Enough to order again. The beef rolls were honestly just okay. They were tasty but not as good as the rolls I had from House of Pancake on Taraval. 

Place is clean and staff is attention enough considering it's a Chinese restaurant. Would come back, but nor running to come back here right away
author: Carissa G.

description:
Honestly, I was watching too many episodes of The Return of Superman and after watching the kiddies on the show devour black bean noodles, I started to get my own cravings.

I scoured the depths of yelp looking for vegetarian jjajangmyeon and found 3 spots opened on a Tuesday night. Just to be sure, I  called all 3 restaurants to see if they offer a vegetarian jjajangmyeon and ended up at Dong Bei Mama. (the other spot will only make it if you ordered 2 servings)

The restaurant was bright, clean and tidy with red lanterns hanging above the ceiling. We were a party of 4 vegetarians and ordered 6 dishes.

1) Beijing style black bean noodle - 5/5
2) eggplant in house made sauce - 4/5
3) vegetarian steamed dumplings - 3/5
4) mixed mushroom pot - 4/5
5) shredded potatoes - 3/5
6) fried salt and pepper tofu - 4/5

Overall, all the dishes were good but a few of them really stood out. The black bean noodle hit the spot! I loved that they took the time to really chop the vegetables very small and bite size rather than a rough chop. The sauce was smoky, flavorful and not too salty. I was a happy camper! 

The eggplant in house made sauce arrived looking very much like fatty pork, it was great eaten with rice but just a little bit oily like most eggplant dishes. 

Pass on the vegetarian dumplings even though they were wrapped oh so beautifully in the shape of a leaf. The fillings was ok and the taste of the dumpling was nothing special in particular. 

They make amazing fried tofu. Each parcel of the fried tofu was cut small and fried excellently, to the point where the crust was thick and crispy, a good ratio of custardy soft tofu and crunch. 

My sister really enjoyed the mix mushroom pot, there was a nice smokey barbecue flavor going on and a generous variety of mushrooms. (not the cheap kind either, I'm looking at you white button mushroom) 

The food came out ridiculously fast and our server was so attentive and sweet, we were debating if this became our new favorite Chinese food spot. Either way, we will definitely be back.
author: Gwendolyn F.

description: This is one of my favorite restaurants in SF!  My two staples are beef pancake and the chicken chow mein.  These two dishes are enough to feed 4 people.  The beef pancake is the BEST thing on the menu.  Everyone I've taken to the restaurant has fallen in love with it, just like I have.  The best part is that you can get tons of food (the portions are huge) and it's really cheap!  The service is great and they get the food out pretty quickly.  I highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Megan M.

description:
Wow, what a disappointment. First of all, we had no idea that this restaurant has become a stopping point for HUGE (I mean three busloads) Chinese tourist groups. That meant they were all served before we were, it took forever to get our food, and it was so unpleasantly loud we couldn't hear ourselves think.  We came on a Saturday around noon.

The food was also ridiculously bland.  We got the xiaolong bao, shrimp and chive dumplings, and spareribs with winter gourd stew. Both dumpling orders were a bust. Super bland and overcooked, like chewy INSIDE - I had no idea people could mess up dumplings so badly.  Save yourself the headache and head to one of the many other dumpling places in the Sunset/Richmond who do dumplings way better.  The stew wasn't bad - decent mild flavor, but the meat was overcooked. Given how bad the experience was, I have no desire to try anything else on the menu.  No thank you.
author: Stephanie L.

description: um...Authentic Dong Bei menu but not the taste. ordered several times from them but not close to our expectation....
author: Xbo Z.

description: YES. Dong Bei Mama, how is this our first meeting? I lived in the Richmond for years and somehow missed this gem. I had to get the two most recommended things that also sounded delicious. The soup dumplings and the beef roll. Amazing. I've never had a beef roll but that was out of this world. Took 3 pieces home and threw them in the oven the next day and still tasty as all get out. Service was great too. I now love this place.
author: Dana J.

description:
Decent Chinese food at a great price. I loved the Dry Hot pot with pork. Very flavorful and a great portion size for the price! Also, we ordered the Dongbei Fried pork (pork fried twice and coated with this sweet tangy sauce) and the beef roll. 

Beef roll was unimpressive. The roll was really thick and the beef was scanty. I wasn't really impressed by this dish at all so I'd def skip the next time. However, service is prompt and portion size is plenty. You pay less than $10 pp and I'm all about that.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Cheap Chinese food in an area where other asian restaurants typically require hours of waiting. I originally wanted to go elsewhere on a friday night with a group of 11 friends. Finding a restaurant in a city that can accommodate a group this large is quite hard. Luckily, Dong bei mama was able to take us. They have large round tables for serving large groups family style like traditional Chinese restaurants. 

While I like the convenience factor of this restaurant, I didn't particularly think any of the food was particularly good. I definitely would not recommend you check this place out for taste while there are so many other better options around. 

one of the other reviewers classify this restaurant as "Shanghainese" that is completely incorrect. First of all: "Dong Bei" refers to the northeast region of China. Shanghai is in the South East region. 

This place definitely serves a combination of more nothern-style food and common american chinese dishes and ABCs (American born chinese) would recognize. With that said, the food is still mediocre and much too oily. For example, if you're looking for jiao zi (dry dumplings with thicker skin than wontons served dry or as pot stickers. this is a specialty of northern chinese cuisine), there are better dumpling shops that aren't too far like Dumpling kingdom. 

¯\(ツ)/¯ they can accommodate large parties at rush hour times. That's worth something.
author: Annie Z.

description:
The food was inconsistent. The stand out dish was the steamed fish and tofu with spicy sauce which featured slices of fish and tofu with strips of ham topped with a black bean and pepper sauce. 

Stewed lamb with pickled cabbage and vermicelli was okay. Like the soup but the lamb was too gamey for my taste. 

Sweet and sour pork was a disaster. I order it for the kids, and they didn't like it. It really seemed like 10% meat and 90% breading. Would not order again. 

Beijing zajiang mian was another dish that came out different than expected. The sauce was a bit too sticky, and tasted different from every other place I've ordered this dish. 

地三鮮 paired eggplants, tomatoes and potatoes in a sauce. The potatoes were sliced thin and fried, so I didn't even recognize them as such at first. 

Beef roll. Massive, giant beef roll that is easily the size of two at any other restaurant. Kid-approved comfort food.
author: Ken C.

description: Yelp reviews were spot on with this great find. The staff was attentive, the food was fresh and great tasting. I recommend you visit with a large group so you can try more of their dishes. We enjoyed the pea shoots with garlic although it's a seasonal dish which was quite expensive for the amount they served.  We also had the soup dumplings and the beef roll which were excellent! We will definitely come back with friends next time.
author: Jack-Carla L.

description: Are you kidding me??!! Beef Pancake was aweful!!! It was all mostly pancake with a Tiny, Tiny, Tiny Dried Up Paper Thin slice of beef but it didn't look like beef or meat for that matter! I also got the Tong Yuen which was very grainy, not smooth and not sweet enough for a desert! I was so glad to find a place that serves this Desert Soup but it was lousy. Can't believe Sacramento has better Tong Yuen!
author: Rod W.

description: Dry sautéed string beans! Shredded Potato with Peppers! Chow Mein! Egg Rolls! Damn. Delicious and one of the best Chinese restaurants in the city! Great flavor for take out too. Yum.
author: Carla M.

description:
My mom is a superb (Taiwanese) home chef and is the type of person that prefers to cook at home rather than go out. This is the first restaurant in the past ten years that I've ever seen my mom want to go to two days in a row for dinner.  It's practically unheard of in my family.

Every other restaurant I've ever taken my mom to, no matter how expensive or how many stars on Yelp, she's always somehow found a way to complain about it a few hours after eating or the next day, or the next time we walk by a place, or even when we try a new place that reminds her of some place we tried before. 

So of course I have to write a review for Dong Bei Mama!

All the food seems freshly prepped and the seasoning is very different from what I'm used to, but still enjoyable.  There seems to be a lot of depth of flavor and complexity.  We ordered a fried chicken wing dish and it just looked like fried chicken wings with a lot of peppers, but it wasn't super spicy, it had this nice smokey flavor, and it wasn't very super salty.  All their dishes that I tried that were fried, whether it was a dry fry or a fried with a glaze or sauce, it was still nice and crispy.  Soups are good and hearty.

The menu is pretty extensive and they have pictures which helps.  I think I saw a lot of dishes that I never really heard of before so I think there's quite a bit of authenticity or tradition to what they make.  Their menu is also split up into regional dishes which is interesting and useful.  Great place to go to for variety.

Good service, food comes out piping hot which makes me think it doesn't sit around for long after it's done being cooked.  All the staff seemed very nice.  My parents talked to them in mandarin.  I don't know how well they speak english, in case that could be a problem for you.  To be honest, my (senile?) dad was being very weird and commented on how handsome the waiter was, to the waiter, and to my surprise the waiter just smiled and tolerated it.

In terms of value, I felt like I was getting a really good amount of food for how much it costs.  Even my mom thought everything was a good value, which is also a very surprising thing to hear my mom say.  We spent about $50-$60 each day and that was about 4-6 different dishes each time, and was plenty of food with leftovers for three people.

It's nice to see a good "authentic / traditional" kind of restaurant with this kind of consistent quality.  The decor is very "homey" and you know, if that means high quality food at a low price, that's OK with me!
author: Anthony C.

description: This place is really good. Their beef fried rice and egg soup are by far the best ones over had. Their walnut shrimp is definitely on the sweeter side. Literally when we walked in, my bf and I were the only ones in the restaurant. 10 minutes later, 3 tour buses come and the restaurant is packed. The servers all do a phenomenal job catering to these tours. With people trying to get into the kitchen and others just simply yelling their orders, the waiters catered to their every need. Even though the restaurant was packed, the waiters always stopped at our table to make sure we were comfortable eating. I would recommend this place. Very happy with their service
author: Becky Mae A.

description:
Dong Bei Mama "go for the food". The restaurant itself has a Old School Chinese restaurant decor with pictures of the food on the walls, glass table tops and wobbly old chairs. Street parking only. According to yelp low health dept. score. 

With that said the food is terrific. The prices are great with large volume of good food. The menu is extensive. Service is excellent. We had the beef pancake roll which was gigantic and was one of the "best" I have ever had. The Tea smoked duck was fatty tender with a deep smoke flavor. Spicy La Tze Chicken was numbing and spicy. The Boiled fish was excellent. Plenty of other dishes to go back for.
author: George F.

description:
Don't speak Chinese? Not sure what to order from their massive menu? Not having been to DBM before but always curious about it, I spent a long time looking over Yelp reviews and feel like my research paid off! My friends & I are big fans of Szechuan food and Mission Chinese Food (szechuan-influenced) and DBM has many similar dishes here as well as dishes from other regions of China.

First of all, the portions are massive and you definitely want to try a bunch of different things so be sure to go with AT LEAST 4 people to make it fun! We went on a Saturday night and there were plenty of big tables open with lazy susans. No need to wait in long lines for the trendy restaurants on Clement Street when you're starving.

No one in our party was vegetarian but we all eat meat, just in small quantities, so you may prefer to order some meat dishes instead of veg/tofu (or maybe some noodles) but here's what we ordered for a table of 5 (plus white rice and complimentary hot tea) and it was the perfect amount of food and only came out to like $60 total. Seriously. And we enjoyed everything!

1. *Cabbage/Pork/Vermicelli Soup* A massive steaming wok on the table with a sterno underneath, this is a Northern Chinese specialty unavailable at most other Chinese restaurants. Our waitress "warned" us it was sour but we all loved it! It kind of tasted like sauerkraut soup, with a delicious lemony and light broth. Be warned, the noodles are very long and kind of hard to serve and slurp.

2. *Beef Pancake* A must try! A gigantic roll bigger than a burrito, cut into slices and plenty of food for 5/6. You only really need one piece each. The chewiness of the roll, sweetness from hoisin sauce, and crunchy coolness of the cucumbers made for nice contracting textures and flavors.

3. *Spicy Chicken Wings* If you love Mission Chinese Food's numbing chicken wings these are like those (Szechuan style with tons of peppers on top) but cut in half, so they're smaller pieces of chicken. Satisfied our numbing spicy craving.

4. *String Beans* One of my favorite Chinese dishes, DMB's is extra salty from those addictive fermented black beans and did not disappoint.

5. *Salt & Pepper Tofu* Awesome crispy outside batter that made the dish, plus silky tofu inside. One of the best tofu dishes I've ever had.

Some other reviews mentioned poor customer service - we did not experience that at all, our waitress was very nice, refilled our water, etc.

If you're looking for a fun Chinese restaurant in the Richmond for large group, especially at the last minute without reservations, Dong Bei Mama is a great spot to try!
author: Alissa A.

description: Spicy sauteed diced chicken was served as finely chopped up chicken wings rathen than boneless. Impossible to eat- do i bite down and crunch the bones or try to pick out each tiny oily piece by hand? Gross
author: Ryan F.

description: Yelp guided us here and it did not disappoint. Our server was very nice and started with a few questions about our tastes. She then recommended some great dishes for us and they were delicious. Definitely coming back here.
author: Waves P.

description:
Props to the memorable and well-thought-out name... not sure how well "Northeast Mom" would have fared. Dong Bei Mama indeed specializes in Northern China cuisine, featuring unique dishes that aren't always on the menu at other Chinese restaurants like the bean sheets appetizer (very photogenic!), spicy pig ears (for adventurous souls), and that braised pork dish that looks like a giant pork belly masterpiece.

Dong Bei Mama is most well-known for the BEEF PANCAKE: it was the primary reason for our visit, and we noticed while walking out that literally every table had ordered it! Although it falls short of the title "the best I've ever had" (blame my 626 food adventures), it was unquestionably the most humongous. Couple the American portion size with the extra-crisp pan-fried cooking style, and it is quite filling. I would have liked more beef and less cilantro, as well as more sauce to balance out all the pan-fried-ness--though the ample cucumber does add a refreshing touch (neutralizing the heat, as explained by my rudimentary understanding of Chinese medicine)

We also got the XIAO LONG BIAO so it would seem somewhat more of a balanced meal than just beef pancake. (Okay not really, since the only veggies were the cucumber and cilantro in the wrap.) For a Northern Chinese restaurant, I expected good XLB, but I thought it was just okay and could have used more soup, thinner skin, and more flavorful pork. Then again,I set unrealistically high expectations based on legendary XLB behemoths like Crystal Jade and DTF. Dong Bei Mama's XLB were not terrible, but serve the purpose as another order-able dish. At the end of the day, it's still all about the beef pancake. 

Ambiance is decent, as a standard nice Chinese restaurant, not some obscure hole-in-the-wall and not a hip fusion place blasting clubbing music. The verdict? Comfy setting with classic comfort food. i.e. BEEF PANCAKE
author: Edna C.

description: Came for Father's Day dinner but the ambiance created by a tour bus of people and the lack of service dropped what would have been a 3-star rating to two.  That, and the show that a mass of roaches put on in their ceiling lights to entertain us while we waited for someone to take notice of us.  Seriously, the silhouette of the scurrying roaches AFTER we had eaten kinda made us wish we didn't.
author: Goph R.

description: A friend wanted to try this place. I wasn't particularly excited because I try to stay away from Asian food when eating out (already eat too much Asian at home). But wow, what a find. They have some very interesting dishes. And very reasonably priced. Would recommend if you're looking for something different.
author: Tinou B.

description: Excellent and authentic. Staff is no-nonsense but attentive. I've had various things here, but my favourites are the lovely beef pancakes (which strike the perfect balance of savoury and crispy with a note of sweet, the best rendition of them I've seen in the city) and the shanghai dumplings, which are pretty solid. Definitely stands out among the plentiful offerings of Chinese food in the Inner Richmond!
author: Eric L.

description: Great food and good size portions.  The beef pancake is really really good and not something I have ever had before.  Parking was super easy on a Friday at 6:45pm.  There are a lot of big tables so it's a great place to go with a large group.  All the food was fresh and it was prepared quickly.
author: Mike M.

description: Wow big portions at really affordable prices. Authentic Taiwanese dishes. We loved the beef pancake, hot and sour soup and especially the braised pork rice dish. The pork soup dumplings was kinda average but good.
author: Linda F.

description: one of the hidden gems of SF for northern chinese food (very rare since everythign is canto here). My favorite items of theirs: beef rolls, pork and sour cabbage soup, all the cold appetizers
author: Mimi M.

description:
Biggest bowl of hot and sour soup I've ever seen.  A great deal at $10.  I'm sure it would serve 10 people.  Delicious.

Some very interesting regional specialties from Northeast China.

A way above average Chinese restaurant.  There is a lot to explore here on this menu.
author: Joe S.

description: Best meal I have had in a very long time. I dont get into the city often. But, from now on I will make a point to eat at this restaurant again.
author: Maura B.

description: Tried this restaurant in Richmond District on Friday evening.  Ordered three dishes: mixed vegetable, sizzling lamb, and broccoli chicken. All dishes were presented very well, color was good, texture was good, and ingredients were fresh.  Will visit again if find a parking.
author: Kirin C.

description: We had the beef roll, three seafood delicacies with sizzling rice, pot stickers, and the steamed pork bun. Everything was delicious!! Nice service, easy to get a table.
author: Christina L.

description:
3.5 stars.

Large restaurant, perfect for groups, dishes are cheap and under $10. The character of this place is interesting. Large Chinese tour groups came in and ate for about 30 minutes and were gone. Then, one server spilled some water and didn't clean it up, and the next server came out and slipped on it. It was like straight out of a cartoon.

FOOD
Beef rolls- 6 pieces, the green onion pancake was thick, pretty good
Boiled fish fillet in spicy sauce- lots of fish, except one piece was undercooked
Spicy beef noodle soup- different from Taiwanese version, broth is spiced with Szechuan peppers, like noodles in a spicy beef broth
Salt and pepper tofu- this was really good. Pieces of flash-fried and battered tofu with a soft interior and crispy exterior.
Kung pao chicken- very cornstarchy, but still tasty
author: Alice T.

description:
Came here for dinner in a Saturday night. We ordered sliced beef pancake, steamed tofu in lotus leaf, spareribs, bean thread and a fish in soup. 

They really need to work on their communication skills and service when serving food. One if the waiters hit me on the arm with the plate of buns knocking 2 of them on the floor. It left my arm greasy. The waiter didn't even apologize or bother replacing the dropped buns. He left the plate of remaining buns on the table and just walked off. Won't be back again.
author: Lorraine G.

description: Classic, authentic Chinese food, comfortable and homey atmosphere. Feels and tastes like home!
author: Teresa J.

description: Vegetarian dishes like the wood ear salad, chili cabbage, and mapo tofu (have to specify vegetarian and no pork) were all very well made. Simple and delicious!
author: Alfred K.

description: This is a very authentic Chinese restaurant whose dishes have very tasty flavors and great aroma. We ordered the pig ear, beef pancake, and chicken with chili and pepper. The food tends to lean towards the spicy side though so if you can't handle the spice then try to stick with the non chili dishes
author: Felisa Z.

description: Best Chinese food we've ever had!  Orange chicken is absolutely delicious!  Melts in your mouth! The service was fantastic!  We will definitely be back next time we are in SF!
author: Natasha P.

description:
Knew to expect deece food x medioc service, but...

Me: "What are tofu puffs?"
Her: "You order or not? If you no order I no talk to you."
Me: "... Ok, thank you."

The fffuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuuu?
Did that just happen?
Yes, that just happened.
Liked what I ate but dang.
author: Dan B.

description: Beef wrap was good, but this restaurant is contracted with big bus tour groups... so if you go when they're there, expect delays
author: Stephanie C.

description:
A big, fat raccoon fell out of the ceiling while we were eating and ran around the restaurant until it made it out the front door into the city. The owner comped all meals and everyone immediately left.. after the raccoon. 

Yelp did warn us...
author: Elaine C.

description:
Hits and misses, but a promising Chinese resturant and I would love to come back sometime with a big group of people and try more dishes.



---- ENTREES ----

Dongbei Fried Pork: 3 stars
Pork was tough but the sauce was tasty and fried well.  Kind of like Sweet n Sour pork or a generic American-Chinese dish like General Tso's though.

Pea shoots with Garlic: 5 stars
Not on the menu, but delicious and gigantic portion. For $14 you will feed four people all the vegetables they need (with rice and a couple of non-veg dishes).
author: Letitia L.

description: BY FAR the best Spicy Chinese food in San Francisco. Get the Fried Fish Wok and you will not be disappointed. Eat here and go to heaven.
author: Logan G.

description:
Their beef roll is SOOOOOO good. This place is worth the trip just for that. I've had some other dishes here like beef noodle soup and dumplings, and they're pretty decent as well. Everything dish has much larger portions than other Chinese restaurants in SF, which is great for a big eater like myself.

The last time I came here, it was dead empty on a Friday night... I mean deeeaaad empty. I hope that this place gets more businesss=, because they make an effort with their service, and it's clearly a small family owned restaurant.

Seriously though, go try their beef roll.
author: Kazu O.

description: It was a quiet Monday night, the restaurant was mostly empty so the service was very attentive. Go with the beef pancake, it's the best I have ever had. The steamed fish on tofu was excellent. The menu is really a bit too large. Skip the Xaio Long Bao (dry, dense, no soup). The yu Xiang eggplant vegetable dish was great! The eggplant was tough and a bit too spicy (for my taste)
author: Jason P.

description:
Food = good.  They have plenty to choose from. And the menu is very large, and a bit overwhelming.  Definitely be prepared for family style sized dishes. 

Sliced beef pancake = ginormous. Enough to share with others.  Or you could eat it alone as a meal. Pancake with sliced beef, vegetables, and herbs rolled and then cut.  It's delicious and hearty.  

Pork a la Sichuan = spicy but not that impressive. Julienned vegetables with pork. Definitely has the red chili oil.

Iron plate beef = tender beef with onions and scallions on a cast iron platter. Slightly sweet, savory and definitely hot when it hits the table.  

Pea sprout leaves with garlic = win. Plenty of delicious pea sprout leaves with sliced garlic. I did not see it on the menu but it was available. 

We ordered steamed rice, too.  (It was hard to skip it with the saucy pork dish.) 

Prices = moderate.  Most dishes are family style.  Our meal was $48 before tip. We had plenty of leftovers as it was just the two of us.  (My friend let me order...oops! lol)  They accept Visa/MC for anything over $20, and they will only allow one card per table, so bring cash if you plan to split the tab. 

Service = friendly and efficient.  Speaking Chinese probably helps but they're okay with English, too.  

Seating = a few 4 tops, and several round tables (seats 8+) with lazy susans, so I'm guessing the more the merrier. 

Parking = street.  Definitely easily accessible by public transit (MUNI buses). 

I'll bring more people next time.
author: Fannie S.

description: Not for me. Came for dim sum, got mushy water buns. I think I'll stick to a better place or better quality of food. Life is to short
author: Paulie P.

description:
We went on Sunday at 7pm on Memorial Day weekend, and you basically don't need to make a reservation since it was pretty empty when we went there, with just a few tables with people inside.

Service: Good
They are quick to fill up your tea pot with tea/water if they see it's empty.  When you are finished with a dish, they are also quick to take the plate away.  The food also comes out really quick.

Food: OK
- Beef pancake: It was good and one of the most popular items that is ordered here, but I wish they added more sauce inside.
- Lamb and napa: The lamb was tender and lamb-y tasting. Was a bit oily.  Wasn't really something I would really want to order.  When eating this on the next day after being in the fridge, you really will notice how much oil was in this dish.
- Salt and pepper tofu: Probably one of the better tasting items.  If I came back again, I would order this again.
- Sweet and sour fish filet: Typical sweet and sour fish, which is probably tilapia - pretty forgettable.  I wouldn't order this again.
- Sizzling rice three delicacies: The rice looked like it would be crunchy, but it's not in squares as it was in the pictures.  It's basically poured into a pan, and then the other items are poured on top, with a variety of veggies, like bamboo shoots, choy and some kind of sauce, turning the rice into a soupy mush, after a while. A definite SKIP on this dish.
- Beef in an iron platter: I thought this might be like mongolian beef from the description, but it isn't and it also includes bamboo shoots and lots of onions. This is a definite SKIP for this dish as well.

Cleanliness: Not really that clean. This is a typical Asian restaurant so the tables are a bit grimy...

Rating: 2.5 stars rounded up to three (I guess...)

Bottom Line: Would I come back? Ehhh... not really by choice...
author: Gilda W.

description: Authentic Chinese food place! The prices seem high because the portion sizes are huge and the dishes are meant to be eaten family style. Their beef roll was like the size of my thigh, so you'll definitely go home with leftovers. I recommend the fish in chili oil and sautéed snow pea leaves (not on menu/seasonal vegetable). I'd pass on the XLB (soup dumplings) because they were just average and there was too much meat to soup. They have pictures of their popular dishes on the menu and everything is numbered so it's easy to order!
author: Sara C.

description: Cheap, delicious, lots of people most times. Friendly staff. I order to go & it's always in a great state.
author: Andrea G.

description: just soso. And I don't know why that there is no people eating around. The restaurant is pretty big. However only two of us are having dinner at 5pm
author: Guanhua W.

description: The waitress trying to convince us to get something else should have been a warning sign, but my friend and I were just in the mood for potstickers so we ignored her suggestion that we supplement our order with something else. Having tasted the potstickers, we now understand why she tried to dissuade us. These are without a doubt some of the worst potstickers I have ever had. They are watery, chewy, and the flavor is awful. We couldn't even finish one order. Two stars because the waitress tried to save us.
author: Meera A.

description:
My parents introduced me to this place. They thought the food was good and that I'd enjoy it as well.

We ordered the:
1. Beef roll (the order is large and tasted okay to me--my parents loved it though)
2. garlic string beans (yum)
3. fried rice steamed in lotus leaf (i didnt see the point in steaming it in lotus leaf. the fried rice was good though)
4. fried pork (my favorite dish, perfectly fried in a sweet and sour type sauce).

When we came they had a group that filled up three large tables. I think it was part of some business tour group.  I'm not quite sure the lady speaks or understands English but I think the menu was in English.  I wouldn't mind coming back here to eat the fried pork again!
author: Janet E.

description: Always come here when I want some Chinese food. The waitress is always nice and remembers me. I always go back there.
author: Paulo R.

description:
I will admit I've only been to a small handful of Chinese restaurants in the city, but I've tried enough to say that this is my favorite spot in the Inner Richmond. Located on always-busy Geary Blvd., Dong Bei Mama is a place you can't miss. The name alone is very memorable! I've dined in several times and each time I am reminded why I enjoy Chinese food so much. So let me get straight into a discussion about the food... In sum: it's fabulous!

I have two favorites: their beef scallion wrap. This burrito-shaped cylinder can easily feed two for a meal or four as an appetizer. Thinly cut beef (with a little fat), scallion, and cucumber are sandwiched between a delicious fried Chinese pancake batter. Despite it being fried, somehow, it also tastes refreshing thanks to the veggies. The dried sauteed string beans is another not-to-miss dish. This is one of my favorite Chinese dishes and they do it very well at Dong Bei Mama. I recently tried their spicy beef noodle soup, and yes, it's very spicy -- at least for me. Each spoonful of the soup kicks you in the mouth. Their honey walnut shrimp is also quite good. And for some reason, I really enjoy the jasmine tea they brew. It's more floral than most complimentary jasmine teas at other restaurants.

The service is not bad. They're always friendly... might be forgetful at times (like bringing water or extra napkins out upon request)... but the food is too good for me to knock them for that. Plus, the prices... for San Francisco standards, this place is pretty reasonable. For example: a recent meal where I ordered the wrap, the string beans, and the soup came out to ~$22 (before tip). Oh, and a quick tip... they are very busy during weekday (and presumably weekend) lunch hours. At Noon, it's suddenly full and then by 1, it's mostly cleared out. Luckily the restaurant can hold quite a bit of people. 

Needless to say, I recommend Dong Bei Mama and I continue to return for their consistently delicious dishes!
author: James Z.

description: I really love this place, great food, good environment, will come back again. 好吃好吃！
author: Fang Q.

description: Food is very good, compare to the Chinese food here in bay area, it's way much over the average
author: Noel L.

description: Great homemade Chinese food. We were lucky to stumble upon this place and will be back the next time we're in the city! Excellent! Such a treat with several vegan options..
author: Robyn H.

description:
"5 stars for the beef pancake roll alone."

That's what I wrote in my draft a few weeks ago.

Being the lazy bum that I am, I rarely push out my reviews until at least a week later, sometimes longer (years...yeah, I can get pretty lazy). But there is the unintentional benefit of objectivity when I go back to seriously write my review and am better able to adjust expectations and impressions.

So now I write "Does their meat lift, bro? Because it's consistently tough."

My friend and I came on a weekday evening to find a spacious, somewhat empty restaurant. We ordered two dishes, the first being the famous $7.89 H01 SLICED BEEF PANCAKES (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dong-bei-mama-san-francisco?select=vzPL2dLrNduSquWsRw2kgA#8PoZjf3DJGH73JGSAgEP3Q). This is essentially a crispy, thick green onion pancake coated with a very thin layer of hoisin sauce (the sauce of my dreams) and wrapped around cold slices of Chinese-braised beef shank, long slivers of cucumber and chives, and cilantro. It is delicious: even though I wasn't hungry, I ate half of it anyway. Which means I'm either a liar or a pig...or both!

Reflecting back on the meal, I was surprised with how light they are with the hoisin sauce, and was pleasantly surprised with how unoily the green onion pancake was. The beef shank slices were a bit tough, but that's how they always are. For true objectivity, I really wanna try the beef pancake roll at Z&Y Restaurant in Chinatown. Dong Bei Mama needs some competition.

Now the bro lifting realization came from our second dish, HUI GUO ROU, translated to twice-cooked pork (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/dong-bei-mama-san-francisco?select=vzPL2dLrNduSquWsRw2kgA#vzPL2dLrNduSquWsRw2kgA). The dish is full of bell peppers, onions, leeks, and long strips of pork belly. Overall, it was a good dish, but I think I'm more a fan of once-cooked pork because I found the meat to be tough and chewy, as if I was eating bacon.

As for the service, the wait staff are fast and speak both English and Mandarin (a rarity, I know).
