They're prompt about refilling your tea (remember to use the Asian signal of the open lid) and cleaning your table. $20 credit card minimum, and they have 2 bathrooms in the back, 1 for ladies and 1 for gents.

My friend, who hails from Northern China, says this restaurant serves legit Northern Chinese food. And when I think about Northern China, I think about Genghis Khan. Now I can associate Northern China with not only tough men, but tough meat too.
author: Adele F.

description: Got dumplings to go and they tasted like those frozen dumplings you warm up in a microwave. Didn't give any soy sauce either.
author: Karla L.

description: Here with a friend from Dong Bei who gives this reataurant a 4.5 for authenticity (he ranks him and his wife's cooking 5 stars). I really liked the fish/tofu and the sweet Yam dessert.
author: Fiona M.

description: My first time being here. I came with my husband and daughter. It was great the restaurant appeared clean, food was yummy, and host was nice. I would have rated this a 5 but I had to ask for drinks and not offered a child seat.
author: Melinda E.

description:
Came here on Friday evening around 6:30. We didn't have a wait and got seated right away unto a big table that would seat 5. We were excited to try a lot of things on the menu with nice big selections of everything from Northwestern Chinese to Sichuan cuisine. We ordered the spicy beef intestines as appetizer, the cumin lamb ribs, sour cabbage dumplings and for dessert, the fried sweet potato wedges coated in thick sugar. 
The spicy beef intestines had a nice Sichuan pepper spice to it, but not overwhelming to the tongue like many other places would make it. The price was also very reasonable for the quantity.
The cumin lamb ribs were yummy, not the same type of stir fried lamb pieces in other Sichuan restaurants. This one is more like a grilled rib with cumin spices sprinkled on top, not marinated through.
The sour cabbage dumplings with pork were good, I had one piece since I was already quite stuffed at this point! Fairly authentic since I'm from the Northwest and my grandma would marinate sour cabbage when I grew up.
The sweet potato wedges were my favorite! It is quite rare to find around the SF area since this is a very Northwestern dish, so not many restaurants serve this or do it the right way. They serve it with a bowl of ice water. You are supposed to pull off a piece of sweet potato from the dish and dip it into the ice water so that the outside will harden and become crispy, SOOOO GOOD! VERY authentic indeed. Each piece is sticky and the sugar coating forms thin sticks connecting each piece to the other. This is exactly how I used to eat it in China.

Overall, I can't wait to come back and try their other dishes, such as beef pancakes, boiled fish, Shanghai soup dumplings, beef noodle soup, and more... I'm drooling again and I just ate....
author: Alice S.

description:
I really really like the food here. Had written a review about it in 2013, and had been coming here from time to time. But there are a few new observations.

To order in a restaurant attempting to please every kind of diner, go for their intended regional speciality. And speak perfect Mandarin in Beijing accent when ordering. That's what you'll need to dine well here. 

I very rarely eat Chinese food with anyone, mainly because my folks make them way better at home. But there are a few things this restaurant has no other places in the bay area has. The cabbage with pork ribs soup is a better option according to the extremely helpful and polite staff. She's from northeastern China, one of the three provinces, I'm guessing Liaoning, could be wrong but that accent is not from Heilongjiang, my cultural heritage. If you speak proper Mandarin, as in with perfect Beijing accent as I did, she'll be very helpful. Ask her what to get between the green beans and the cabbage, she tells me that she'd go for the cabbage, as the green beans would have been cooked too long. I wholeheartedly agree. My grandma used to make this. It came as in a pot that filled with yam noodles and soup, white soup that was so delicious for a cold winter day. My companion is a Midwestern transplant, and he was so delighted. For a white guy he was very adventurous and I was impressed that he liked the dish. 

I ordered the bean sheet salad. It's less than $10 and it's exactly what I liked, things like that only made by my father during Chinese New Year. And the egg omelette salad that is part of the dish was as good as it gets. It's slimy. Unless you grew up in Manchuria and had that as a kid, I suspect you won't like it. But if you were like me and had that dish growing up, this is as good as it gets, better than most of the northeastern Chinese restaurants I have eaten at in Southern China or Beijing. They make it spicy too, with Sichuan peppers, so it's a nice twist to an otherwise completely northern dish. I'd skip the shrimp or the ham, and instead of it, I'd add the Moscow sausage or the blood sausage from Europa Plus which is just down the street. In Northeastern China, our food has a lot of Russian and German influences, stemmed from its close proximity (Russia) and prior colonial influence (Germany). 

The last but not the least is the beef onion pancake. It has sliced cucumber and cilantro, plus the marinated and thinly sliced beef. It's a better version than what I'd get in Beijing, though very Americanized, as in the size is huge.

Portion and value are unprecedented in the bay area, and I'd venture to say, the quality of ingredients and the preparation are far more superior than most of the northeastern restaurants I've dined at in China. 

Three things we ordered that night: cabbage and pork rib soup, the beef pancake, the bean sheets salad. We ate until we were about to explode from fullness. And then we took the rest of home. We got two extra meals out of it. 

The lady who served us was quite nice. She reminded me of the kind hearted, well mannered northerners that I met when I was a young girl and visited / lived in Manchuria. It's a very rare sight. I suspect my impeccable Beijing accent made her at ease as well. But being half northerner myself, I know the hospitality of northerners is famous in China, it really makes dining out a treat. 

There are many dishes to get here. Like I said, it's a crowd pleaser and they do what they can to attract different types of diners. It is trying to do too much. Sichuan, Cantonese, Yunan and Northeastern food. They cannot be good at everything. I would not go there for those regional cuisines if you know what the restaurant's name meant: "Northeastern Mother". You go there to order the food that the northeastern Chinese eat: think home made sauerkraut, stewed cabbage, and noodles. 

The three things we ordered seemed to shine above other things, it feels like that these could be their signature dishes. They did those dishes extremely well and food arrived super fast.

A few nights ago I couldn't sleep and I was browsing Yelp's photos of the restaurant. I sent him photos and reviews of this place. He said to me, "You really want to go there, we should go there, you miss home." 

I'm not sure if I was missing home. I was probably missing my childhood in Manchuria, and my grandparents and my father who made those dishes for me growing up. That evening after dinner I slept very well. Curled up like a baby and did not wake up until 8. I think my grandparents who were now heaven, they were watching over me that night, and they were smiling because I have finally found a place in America that made food just like they did.
author: Victoria E.

description: Our Airbnb landlord told us to come to this part of town and search for Asian or Indian food. So we found this gem on Yelp and decided to give it a try. It was SOOOO delicious!!! We are all vegetarians and they accommodated our needs with veggie dumplings, a string bean ginger stir-fry and a veggie fried rice. And each of them were sooo delicious. Very clean, not overly greasy like other places, tasted fresh and the string beans were even crunchy, because they made them right there and then. Delicious!!! The waitress was very kind and prompt and even advised us not to order a 4th dish.   The food came fast. Additionally, given this part of town is a away from the touristy area, we got a parking spot right in the front of the restaurant and there was a lot more available, even being Father's Day Sunday. A total 5 stars experience!!! Highly recommend it!
author: Diana S. T.

description:
Not a pleasant experience. The pork has a funny mint flavor, their GuoBaoRou is totally unacceptable - not a genuine Northeast China cuisine.

Update: further disturbed by Yelp's poor food safety warning.
author: Eric Y.

description: Cuisine is phenomenal and Kelly is consummate chef, hostess, with the biggest heart and smile! Will be my go to restaurant, eat in, take out, party caterer.
author: Ellen L.

description:
I was looking forward to this place because of the reviews, but it doesn't reflect the 4 stars it received on Yelp. Food was just ok and service was lacking, despite how NOT busy they were. If you order soup, most restaurants serve that to you first. That's not the case here. 
All of our dishes came out, but half way we realized that we didn't even receive our soup yet. By the time my family and I were full and basically ready to pay the bill, that's when soup came to our table. We ended up having to take a large soup togo. Also, their XLB isn't worth it. I was excited, but was very disappointed. The only dish I enjoyed was the one with fish and tofu and their orange chicken dish; however, I don't know if I'd come back.
author: Jerlynn M.

description:
I was so looking forward to XLB dumplings but was disappointed when the dumplings came out undercooked. The pork was still pink and tasted like it was just rolled up and brought out to our table. The chow fun was tasty and fried pork pancake was good but the undercooked XLB freaked me out. They were kind enough to remove the dumplings from our bill. 

The little fruit flies flying all over the sauces kind of made things more unappetizing. Sadly I won't be back.
author: Becka T.

description: Wow, this place was a great find from the time I spent exploring yelp for some Beef rolls! My boyfriend is Taiwanese and loves beef rolls, so I decided to take him here for his birthday lunch. It was not packed when we came in, but there were a handful of big groups seated at their tables. Nonetheless, the food came out quickly and hot. The beef noodles stew was AMAZING. It was huge and delicious. I would definitely come back just for their beef noodles. I almost must warn you, their beef rolls are MUCH bigger than they appear in these pictures. My boyfriend and I were shocked by how gigantic they were compared to the ones we usually get back in SoCal. Thankfully, my boyfriend thought they were authentic enough for his liking. For me, however, I thought they were a little dry and didn't take more than one bite. Their service was alright, nothing to rave about.
author: Christine C.

description: First time to this restaurant with a group of friends.  The food was good, the beef wrap was good, taste like sandwich wrap has good favor.  The Napa cabbages with tofu soup was good, the veggie dumpling was good, the chives stir fry dry bean cure was average.  The least favorite was the sweet and sour pork chops, was chewy, fat meat. The chicken stew was taste funny would be best if beef stew instead plus there was some bones.  Overall not too bad food.  However, there was gnats after gnats at our table, trying to fan it out with our hands was really something else. The service not so much, we barely finished already a bill for us when we didn't asked.  Plus, it was not long line or customers waiting either.  We paid but we have friends and continue with our conversation, but, the service really stop here. No more tea or water filling up plus wait stuff avoid eye contact with us.  Sorry service is no good!
author: Kitty L.

description: Except Liao Ning Restaurant in New York City, this is the most authentic Dongbei cuisine in US, especially West coast. Declious food with taste from hometown.
author: James W.

description:
Been here a few times now, and there are definitely some standout dishes:
- Beef pancake (5/5) - As good as all the other reviewers have claimed.  Great combination of crispy and gluteny Chinese pancake, flavorful meat, hoisin, scallions, and cucumbers.  Not to mention it's massive and super cheap.
- Spicy boiled beef (5/5) - Tender, melt in your mouth beef, along with napa and bean sprouts, submerged in mala numbing spicy sauce.  Could have used even more spice, but very good.
- Green beans (5/5) - Obligatory vegetable dish that's actually pretty delicious.
- Lamb dumplings (4/5) - Really concentrated lamb flavor.
- Xiaolongbao (3/5) - Pretty average dumplings.
- Preserved napa with pork belly (3/5) - A little disappointing, as the broth and meat were pretty bland.

Overall, this place has good food, huge portions, and awesome prices.  You could easily stuff yourself for less than $10.  Worth the drive all the way from SOMA every time.
author: Simon L.

description:
Come here if you want:

1. Interesting Chinese food
2. Friendly/Quick service
3. Decent pricing

This place just happened to be outside the motel we were staying at, so we decided to check it out. The beef pancake got better the more we ate it and only cost around $7.50 (it had a little too much cilantro though). It could easily feed 2 people. Don't order the corn cakes alone, they were okay but usually come with something else. We also ordered some Shanghai pork buns, which were decent but nothing that special. The staff was very friendly and food came quick. 

To sum it all up: One step away from being really great.
author: Kevin I.

description:
It's tough to find a restaurant that serves good northern Chinese cuisine and, man oh man, this place hits the spot. I came here with my parents and we absolutely love the place. The portions are HUGE and the service friendly and efficient. No wonder a lot of tour buses drop their customers here for lunches.

We ordered the noodles with meat sauce, the oil braised bamboo shoots, bean sprouts sauteed with garlic, the lamb steamed dumplings, the sliced beef wrapped in pancake and the xiao long bao. My favorites were the bean sprouts (the waitress suggested it because it was in season), the pancake wrapped beef and the lamb dumplings. 

I would skip the xiao long bao, the other reviewers were right, the skin is too thick and not enough juice, although the flavors are pretty good. The ground pork sauce noodles weren't amazing, either, although it's a huge serving.

If I order one thing, I would be the beef pancake. This is why I'm giving the place 5 stars instead of 4. It's crispy on the outside, had a touch of peiking duck sauce smeared inside, delicious thinly sliced roast beef and some raw scallions and cucumber for crunch/spice. Man, one of the best things that I've eaten in SF. Love love love!! I can't wait to come back with a bigger group and try more things.
author: Alice W.

description:
I can summarize our last meal with one word: "DIRTY!!!"
The table is greasy and lazy Susan is disgusting and not working. 
The floor is covered with grease and dangerous to walk on. 
The food is 2 and half stars.
author: Ben G.

description:
Came here out of my way to find the best beef roll in town. I think I FINALLY found it after being a guinea pig to numerous places. THE BEEF ROLL IS A MUST ORDER ITEM!!!! I am not exaggerating when I say their beef roll is HUGE like seriously for that price! It is def well worth it and they are not stingy to their filling. To put in perspective of how big the roll is, I'll compare it to like a burrito cut into smaller portions. 

This is THE place if you got cravings for those beef rolls, but I will def try other things as well! YUM YUM!!!
author: Cindy L.

description:
Came around 8 pm on a Saturday and there was no wait for tables. We got the beef pancake, dong  bei pork leg, Westlake beef soup, salt and pepper tofu, preserved Napa with pork belly, and sizzling rice three delecasies.

The beef pancake is a must. It was very unlike other beef pancakes I have had because they basically put what you'd get with Peking duck wraps inside a green onion pancake with thinly sliced beef. So good!

The dong bei pork leg was very tender but other than that, not too special.

The Westlake beef soup was great. A small size is already pretty big and enough for 5 people.

The salt and pepper tofu was the way you'd expect it to be. Some pieces were a little too oily/soggy but overall still good.

The sizzling rice three delecasies was interesting. It's like that one dish where you have crispy noodles and you pour sauce over it to get it soft but you still have the crunch but instead of noodles, this dish had rice. Good.

Now, the manager (I think?) Recommended the preserved Napa with pork belly. I've had this at other restaurants before. It was a different name on the menu so I didn't know what to expect until it came and I heard the waiter say the name of it in chinese. I normally don't like this dish because of the sour vegetables and this time was no different. I thought it was redundant for her to have recommended a soup when we already ordered one but she was raving about how it was the food of her country and made it sound like it was a must try so we gave it a shot. Not worth it unless you actually really like preserved Napa (suan cai).

I enjoyed all the food we chose but not so much the recommendation.

All those dishes plus rice came out to about 60 dollars which to me was pretty reasonable. I'd come again if I was in the neighborhood.
author: Christine L.

description:
Poor food safety score? No care!! Great beef noodle soup :) :)

I've had both the spicy version and the "regular" version. I actually prefer the regular version.. the broth in this one is so much more flavorful. I feel that the spicy version is overpowered by the numbing spice.

Beef pancakes are huge... I'm in general not a fan, but my friends really liked it.

I would not recommend the xiao long bao (soup dumplings). They were kind of dried out (very little soup) and lacked flavor.
author: Stephanie L.

description: The stir fry lamb was amazing. The fried rice was also very good. I highly recommend the beef pan cake. The dry woke beef has a very unique and delicious taste. The only problem was I ate too much because it was all soooo good.
author: Suzy G.

description: Great service! Food came very quickly! Over the course of our lunch, several tour groups came and dined.
author: Kathy K.

description:
Awesome chinese food place in the city. The top things to get here are: 

-salt and pepper tofu
-beef rolls
-dou miao (garlic pea shoots) that aren't on the menu 

This place has awesome food yet is for some strange reason always empty. The service has always been pretty good, since there aren't many other tables for the servers to distract themselves with.
author: Derrick W.

description:
Yay! This place is delish! Much better than my 1st experience here 5 years ago. Here's why:

1）The food is delish! Lots of robust flavor without the MSG hangover. (At least in my opinion)

2) Hot and sour soup- very tastey with huge portions

3) Boiled Szechuan fish filet- only ok. I am used to my fish swimming within chilli oil/whole peppers. This place just had the filet with sauce and chilli flakes poured over it.

4) Scallion pancake- two thumbs up

5) Beef wrapped in scallion pancake- husband loved it! Btw, it is HUGE

Overall, we really like this place. However I would recommend going with a native Chinese speaker as this a VERY authentic experience.
author: Tracy C.

description:
Maybe we just ordered the wrong dishes, because I thought everything was just okay. The only thing that stood out to me was the SHEER SIZE of all the dishes.

An order of rice for ONE person totaled $1.25 and turned out to be an entire potful of rice that could've easily served four. 

An SMALL order of West Lake Beef soup for less than $7 was a ginormous bowl that could've fed six. This was extremely packed with MSG, by the way (which isn't that surprising in hindsight), and I would caution you to avoid it. 

The dishes were sized for big tables or families, not the small groups of 2-3 that we saw when we went for dinner.

We also ordered the shanghai dumplings, which were nothing to rave about. The skin was thicker than average, and there wasn't much soup inside the dumping. The meat inside also had less ginger than I'm used to. They're not bad dumplings though, just not anything spectacular.

I also ordered the iron platter seafood tofu, but it's nothing amazing either. Not what I was expecting in comparison to what I've tried in Beijing. The tofu SHOULD actually be short cylinder shaped with a thin layer of smooth skin around the outside like this picture: http://pic4.nipic.com/20090828/988505_154330003482_2.jpg
NOT the cubed shaped tofu that we were served with the dried skin on the outside. That was a bit of the cop-out tofu if you ask me. Maybe you just can get this kind of tofu in the States, I'm not sure.

Next time, I'm going to try the stews or the hot pot with corn bread...
author: Audrey L.

description:
Returned again many many many times and got their beef pancake and a million other dishes and yummmo...pancakes are a must get. It's huge!!! 

Must try: sizzling rice seafood, steam fish with tofu, lotus leaf fried rice, the list goes on and on. 

Great prices and out of this world food! We will be going again on Friday and I can't wait! Mmmm that beef pancake is calling for me.
author: W W.

description:
Had a Bday party here on Friday night; about 30 people jammed this tiny eatery.

The spicy fish served in oily red broth was tastey and so were the various stif fry and saute veggies. All veggies were good tasting and not over cooked. 
Noodles: yes, ton's of noodle dishes here!
I enjoyed the various noodle dishes; some with 4 mm wide darker flat noodles (typical Northern style?! ) and other dishes with 10 mm wide clear glass noodles.
The breaded walnut shrimps were standout; some how , they had a lemon zing to the flavor - Nice!

We had three tables of ten and each table had some food left over; good sized portions here.

Tea quality: good

Good value here.

Decor: ok, homey.

Customer service: fine.

Parking: typical SF, you will drive around for 10 minutes, unless your middle name is Lucky!

Bathroom: needs work.
author: Bert K.

description:
2 n half stars 
I went there with a bunch of friends on saturday nite, the place was had about 2-3 tables occupied.I wanted to try this place so we went. We ordered the beef roll which was ok , we also had beef in red chilli which imo was the best dish we. I ordered 4 more dishes and they said we dont have any of the sauces used to cook the dishes , at that point I just ordered there name sake chicken dish. It never came out. The service lacks
author: Jorm K.

description:
Executive Summary: Excellent Value; Ok Food

We stopped by Dong Bei Mama after our beach outing. It was past lunch time and we were extremely hungry. You know when you go grocery shopping on an empty stomach and you end up buying twice as much food as necessary? Yup, that was us. Way too much food!

We ordered the obligatory beef pancake, the northern stir fried bean threads dish, deep fried tofu cubes, and potstickers. The beef pancake was 2x the size I expected it to be. It's not nearly as good as the pancakes I'm used to from 101 Noodle Express in the SGV but they were good enough. The potstickers were ok as well; I could've made it better at home. For me, the standout was the stir-fried bean threads dish. I love the texture of "lapi."

Service was pretty spotty but that was expected from a Chinese restaurant. The restaurant was good enough for me to want to go back but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit Dong Bei Mama.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Chong Qing Spicy Fish!!! Xoxoxo!! That numbing spice is perfection. Boneless, crispy, mouth numbing, but so so well flavored. I'm dreaming about it now... Insert Homer moan/drool.

I'm not a huge fan of sweet with salty, but those beef rolls are also bomb. Big tables, quick and friendly service. Perfect for large groups. There are lots of China tours that stop here, so their kitchen is accustomed to making things fast. When you want an excellent, affordable, family style meal, Dong Bei Mama knows best.

Also that taro red bean pastry is good, and I don't even like red bean (yeah go ahead, try to take away my Asian card.. Nope not happening). They sometimes ask if we want it served toward the end of your meal. Do it. 

Decor is lacking but focus on what's about to be in your face.. Magic and numbing spices..
author: Donna H.

description: Everything I've tried is delicious. Beef pancake, shredded potato, smoked tea duck, dumplings....
author: John W.

description: I have gone here three times now and really enjoyed each time. I'm a bit disappointed to see that they recently received a low health score, but assuming that they can get this fixed, here's my review of their food. Their dumplings are a little different but no less tasty than the ones at King of Noodle and San Tung. They don't have as extensive a dumpling menu, but the ones they served were solid. I like how their menu is pretty diverse and spans quite a few different regional cuisines in China. Service is good and this location is great for groups. I've never had to wait to get seated and I've come on various weekend evenings during dinner time. Portions are quite large so make sure you bring a few people or be prepared to take home leftovers. I've ordered the winter melon and pork bone "stew" on multiple occasions and really love this dish. One time I ordered it, the dish came out under cooked, but once I pointed this out to the staff they were more than happy to take the dish back and bring us another one that was really tasty. The beef pancake, while good, is enormous, so I only recommend ordering that dish if you have 4+ people.
author: Alice H.

description: Loved their spicy chili chicken wings and stir fry green beans. Shanghai dumplings were okay.
author: Lillian W.

description: Service was so friendly and quick. Portion size is very generous. Loved the beef pancake and would order again. The hot and sour soup was tasty and I somewhat addicting. Salt pepper tofu was light and fluffy you must try. I will return for sure.
author: H G.

description: Northern Chinese food and spicy food are good this restaurant. I like their House Special Bean Sheets. Varieties of dishes on the menu. Beware they do serve big tour groups from the mainland China and will occupied all the seats at lunch hour. Some dishes were a little bit too oily. Price was affordale. Overall everything were satisfied.
author: Katherine L.

description: Big portions and authentic sit down, hole in the wall type of place. The rolled beef pancakes were delicious, as well as the steamed fish fillet over tofu. The food is worth the experience and there were plenty of leftovers for another delicious meal the next day.
author: Sophia C.

description:
I'm disappointed. Disappointed that one day a food blogger will discover this place and ruin my secret favorite place in the Richmond district. Generous portions

Beef roll pancake. Enough said. Come here for that alone. Perfect crisp to the roll and amble amount of beef in the roll.

Also don't missed the hand torn noodles. 

Also Braised Fish Fillet with tofu - great price for under $10. My gf and I felt full on less than $25.
author: Calvin C.

description:
This place made a good first impression. Clean, full of people, and yummy food smell when you walked in. However, it quickly went downhill from there. The service was pretty good and the food came out quickly. As we ate people left but no new people came in. Halfway through our meal the restaurant was deserted. The waiters sat in the corner on their phones. Wow. 

I don't remember everything we ordered but here's what I do remember.

- Xiao Long Bao
- Beef Pancake Wrap
- Salt and Pepper Fish Fillet

We also ordered a hot pot but it was just so so. The XLB was a little dry. Not juicy enough and not flavorful enough, but decent. The beef pancake was tasty but kinda cold when it got to our table. We really liked the fish. All the other dishes were bland. 

This one is a no for me.
author: Cindy K.

description:
3.5 stars

My bf and I came here for dinner on a Tuesday night and it was pretty empty - only 2-3 other groups around 8pm. We ordered the beef pancake, beef noodle stew, pan fried pork buns, and bok choy + mushrooms. We knew we ordered a lot, but we didn't expect the ginormous portions that we received haha. The beef pancake and pan fried pork buns were huge! The beef pancake was good, but pretty dry and I liked the pork buns, but they needed more pork and less bun. The beef noodle stew was delicious, but too spicy for me to enjoy the broth. :( but FYI, I don't tolerate spicy food well, sadly. 

All of this amounted to only $32, and we had so much food left over! I prefer Dumpling Kitchen over this place, but I would come back for their beef noodle stew and ask for less spicy next time haha.
author: Stephanie G.

description: We've only ever ordered take out but they have always been friendly and fast. The food is so damn good, we may or may not have ordered it more than once in a weekend. Our favorite items are the crispy spicy prawns (order WITH shell, I promise it's good!), Kung pow chicken and beef chow fun.
author: Nelly W.

description:
This is going to be a very biased rating based on pretty much only the beef roll and pea sprouts. Both of these are dishes that my family prepares. Being away from home, they bring me so much comfort and happiness! 

The beef roll is basically the poor mans Peking duck. My family usually makes different veggie/meat dishes with the Peking duck wrapper and add green onion + sauce to it. Also the portion is huge. I could probably get three meals out of just this one dish.

The pea sprouts were somehow extra delicious here, can't really specify what it is.

I've also tried a couple of other dishes like the spicy beef noodle soup and fried tofu. Those were pretty average and you can probably find better choices elsewhere. 

We went pretty late at night and were pretty much the only party there. The owner got into a pretty intense argument on the phone in Chinese. Rather than going to the back kitchen, she stayed at the very front of the restaurant and was pacing back and forth. I found it amusing and tried to get a gist of they were arguing about (I'm nosey and I don't deny it hehe). However, I can see potential for other customers to find it bothersome.
author: Beryl Y.

description:
Ventured out to Richmond because I heard that this is were locals got authentic and delicious Chinese food. The food really left something to be desired.

I ordered 3 things: the Xiao Long Bao (soup dumplings), Stir-fried french beans, and the lotus-wrapped rice. The soup dumplings contained little to no soup. There was too much filling in the dumpling and the filling was not flavourful. I can't say I've ever had a soup dumpling with no soup... There's a first for everything!

The stir-fried french beans puzzled me when it came to the table. Typically, the beans are stir-fried with ground pork but there was none in this dish! The beans had a strange and tough "skin" as a result of the deep frying... This texture made it hard to eat.

The lotus shrimp rice was flavourless. Imagine plain white rice, steamed. That's what it tasted like. Sprinkle lots of ground white pepper & douse with hot sauce for best results.
author: Cindy T.

description: Opens late, delicious food, large portions, and cheap.... What's there to complain about?? Gigantic beef package roll (bigger than a chipotle burrito) with crispy skin and tasty insides. Flavorful pork belly and pickled cabbage hot pot... So sour and salty, yum!!! Lastly, the lamb skewers are delicious. Juicy!
author: Betty T.

description:
This place is 3.5 stars for the food and service, but their portions are HUGE & for the price, you get a damn good deal

Came w/a friend who isn't too adventurous on asian food, but I'm usually understanding and can accommodate to that. We ordered Shrimp Chives Pork Steam Dumpling, Orange Chicken, & Beef Chow Mein. I wasn't expecting much since these were pretty mediocre orders, but when they came out, I was shocked. The portions were hugeee,& each served on large round plates. The food didn't amaze me as they were basic, but they were filling and delicious nonetheless. Also, splitting the bill b/w 2 ended up only being abt $12!! For 3 orders, that's a good value.

Overall, really impressed by the value of the food & how big the portions are. Definitely gnna come back here to try out their beef pancakes&other yummy items
author: Trina N.

description:
I would say this place is a 3.5 since its REALLY great portion size for value, food is decent, but service is poor, even for a Chinese joint. 

We got the spicy pig's ear (standard size/solid), beef noodle soup (standard/meh), dumplings (a solid dozen/solid), salt-pepper tofu (large/very good), beef pancake roll (wtf large/very good) and the dong po pork (WTF GIANT LEG OF PIG/meh). 

The giant leg of pig was not really cooked dong po ro style, it was more like ti pang (hoof), so calling it dong po ro is kind of a misnomer. If you're looking for a straight meat injection though, I can't imagine a better deal than this ($11). And the beef pancake was $8 and about the size of my arm, so also a great deal. 

All in all, this would be a great place for a big group dinner. As I'm writing this, a tour bus is unloading about 30 people into the restaurant so, case in point.
author: Diana L.

description: Carries the beef roll. Just as good as MY China and it's 4x as large.
author: Ingrid K.

description: I only liked their sliced beef pancake here. Their soups are too bland for me. I don't know if I would come here again. Maybe my expectations were too high and we didn't order the right things.
author: Shu T.

description:
Pretty good mix of authentic Chinese dishes and american styled Chinese dishes. I've had the chance to try out a few of beef and lamb sizzling plates, and they are both quite good, although I wish that they came with moar meats. 

This place also makes a pretty mean beef roll, and it's humongous, can't say the exact size but it's definitely much much bigger than any other beef roll that i've ever seen (that's what ... ahh never mind). 

Aside from the deliciously cooked foods, you also get the added bonus of flipping through the menu, which has some hilariously bad stock photos. My favourite is the picture of a napa cabbage, linked with a dish with napa cabbage in it.
author: David C.

description:
Based on the sliced beef pancake and sauteed snow pea leaves, I'd definitely come here again to have those two dishes alone. The dishes were not too greasy and the flavor was just right.

Sliced beef pancake roll- 5 stars and highly recommend: This could probably feed 3 people easily; the dish is a lot bigger than expected! The flavoring is really yummy; the sliced beef reminds me of typical Chinese cold sliced beef and the sauce is what they use for Peking duck. Great flavor and super delicious...still wish I had leftovers...
Sauteed Snow Pea Leaves (Dou miao)- 5 stars: Excellent! The leaves were very fresh and the hint of garlic was great! They used the right amount of oil; enough to make it tasty and not too much to make it overly greasy. 
Shanghai soup dumplings- 2.5 stars: I'm particular about my soup dumplings and they were just okay. To me, the skin was a little too thick and the broth/meat filling wasn't spectacular. I'd skip this dish if you had a choice.
author: Lillian C.

description: Some dishes' flavors have been modified worse. The ingredients of meat are not fresh. Services are very good.
author: Annie Y.

description:
I have driven by Dong Bei Mama a thousand times. It took a lot of courage to step foot in this building. You see this use to be Panda Country Kitchen...Perhaps the worst most disgusting Chinese food on the planet....oh where was I....yes.

I always notice the tour buses carrying hoards of mainland Chinese to this restaurant...that and it is pretty clean...a major plus in my book.

Decided to take the plunge and I am glad that I did. Dong bei is a really good restaurant serving some very good Szechuan dishes(and  other region cuisines as well)...a cuisine I truly adore. 

I started with the beef pancake: Delicious. More like a sandwich/calzone??? than a pancake. Filled with delicious thin slices of beef, onions and other spices. I loved the texture of the pancake..it was crispy yet soft on the inside.

Great Mao po tofu....really hot and very flavoful with wonderful textured tofu in an amazing sauce....really large portion too.

Salt and pepper fish. Basically a battered and fried fish cuttlet with great seasoning. I also like that it  was not greasy and pretty light and crunchy.

The final dish was a cumin chicken hot plate. Friggin awesome, very aromatic, with delicious flavors....you must like cumin, obviously, but it is not over powering. I loved the sichuan peppers and onions mixed in....wow it was a treat.

Prices are very good for the amount of food you get.

I found service to be okay and very fast.

This is  a hidden gem in the inner Richmond.
author: David G.

description:
Came here for dinner around 730.  At the time it looked sleepy, but only because a literal tour-bus load of people had just finished a meal and had exited the restaurant en masse and were milling outside.

Ordered three things.  Lamb dumplings, beef pancake, and the spicy beef noodle soup.  All three were great.  The only small issue I had was that the beef pancake was unlike any other version I've had before - in other places it was always a nice, compact roll made with a thin green-onion pancake.  This one was monstrous by comparison.  I thought it was well made and flavourful, but not something I would order in conjunction with other items as it clearly could stand alone as a meal itself.  The spicy beef noodle soup could have been spicier, but as a dish meant to be served to a wide audience, I can say that it hit a reasonable middle ground.
author: V. Y.

description: This place has very fast service! I am a vegan and they had a lot of vegan dishes that were delicious. The vegetable lo mien was amazing!
author: Izzy N.

description: Mediocre dongbei food. I feel like a dongbei place needs to do one dish right, and that's suancai, the northeastern sauerkraut. The suancai pork belly stew tasted like something from a can. The dumplings were horrible. The green beans, served with a dark suancai, were fine. The much-lauded beef pancake, which was on every table in the restaurant, was pretty good.  Overall, mediocre.  Beef pancake was a must-order, but only if you're already here.
author: Andy D.

description: Great place to go! The food is really really authentic. It takes a minute to get all the dishes ready to eat. So impressive!! Also, No need to wait for a seat!! Everything is perfect
author: Wenjun W.

description: I am from China ,when I eat that food ,I really miss my hometown ,it is really from China and real China food,nice restaurant nice services,beef cake really yum!
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Ordered three things:

1. salt and pepper tofu - crispy and flavorful! seasoning reminds me of popcorn chicken

2. beef pancakes - big enough to feed a village. Delicious and awesome value

3. sautéed pea sprouts with garlic - healthy and strangely refreshing, however they charged me $14.89 for this dish! REDONKULOUS. The waitress' explanation was that "pea sprouts is not on the menu, and the current market price for pea sprouts is very expensive". My deepest sympathy for the restaurant owner for having to pay $15 for a pound of pea sprouts. Let me introduce you to New May Wah, a grocery store on Clement street. Pea sprouts over there cost less than $3 per pound. I believe your vegetable supplier had mistaken the price of lobsters for pea sprouts.  

4 stars for the food and service minus 1 star for the price of pea sprouts. My friend and I ended up paying $40 for the three dishes listed above, when we were expecting to pay around $30.
author: Yummytummy W.

description: Very solid Northern Chinese food. We got the noodles, beef rolls, whole fish, dumplings, and a few other side dishes - then regretted ordering so much food once we realized that the portions are huge. The whole fish is delicious and really good value. Beef rolls and dumplings are solid as expected. Noodles are tasty but a little heavy on the szechuan peppercorn. All in all, definitely satisfied my dongbei food craving! (Sidenote: I wasn't too bothered by Yelp's "food safety" warning. They actually seemed fairly clean for your average Chinese restaurant; these guys probably just didn't pay off the right people at Yelp.)
author: Ibby S.

description:
Ummmm, I was the only non-chinese person here and I WAS LOVIN' IT.  This place is so legit.  I came after going to the beach and brought that post-beach hunger with me. 

Like a total noob, I thought my 103lb self can totally handle a beef pancake. WRONG!  I am quite the pig and eat like a beast when hungry but this damn beef pancake -- no matter how delicious and fresh the cucumber inside was -- was TOO much for me.  IT IS HUGE.  This beef pancake was bigger than my face, my book that I was reading..my life!

Definitely share the pancake with at least 2-3 other people OMGAHHH so damn delicious
author: Mia F.

description:
I'm someone who eats a LOT of Chinese food and bar none, this is my favorite spot in SF to go for Chinese. The portions are big, the food is authentic and they have a ridiculous amount of space so there's never a line even if you have a huge party.

If you are looking for what food actually tastes like in China, this is the place to go. In fact, not only do I personally bring my Chinese friends visiting here, a large portion of DBMM's business is from Chinese tour groups who come all the way to America and eat here (that's when you know it's authentic!).

The food is Northern cuisine (much more flavorful, garlic/leek-heavy vs. Cantonese/Americanized places) and you should definitely venture out of your Chinese food comfort zone when ordering here, since many of their best dishes are ones that a typical Chinese restaurant won't even have. Also, the main waitress is super nice and helpful and if you ask her for a recommendation or about food allergies, she's more than happy to help (my girlfriend is vegan and has lots of food allergies and has no problem eating here).

My recommendations:
+ Beef pancake and beef noodle soup are both really popular here and you should DEFINITELY get them
+ Spicy beef in dry wok (gan guo niu rou), great choice for the first-timer. Classic Chinese dish with a lot of flavor and really tender meat
+ Preserved napa with lamb is a traditional Northern dish and one of their specialties. The taste is very unique (sour-savory taste) that may not be for everyone. But if you like classic Northern or even Korean food, this is something you'll probably enjoy
+ Salt and pepper tofu. I don't even like tofu usually but this dish is delicious. Also for your vegan friends, this dish is good-to-go with no modifications
+ Fish filet slices with tofu on top (forgot the actual name). My go-to for the seafood lovers. Unlike Chinese people from China, I do not know how to eat fish with the bone inside. Fortunately, this delicious dish does not have any
+ Ask for a recommendation! Any time I want to try something new, I just tell the waitress to pick something out for me. Not once has this failed me

Skip:
+ Potstickers, as they have too much dough. On the other hand, for the vegans, the vegetarian dumplings are quite good
+ The Sichuan inspired dishes. It's not bad per se, rather just not their specialty. If you REALLY like Sichuan, by all means but there are other places with much better Sichuan food
+ The quality of the food can be a little uneven on the weekdays, but weekends/Friday are pretty consistent
author: David L.

description:
Dry [-----------------[X] Oily

Honestly, the food was inedible due to how oily it was. I'd suggest eating your money for a more substantial meal.
author: Thomas W.

description:
It's obvious we didn't order the right items so we'll need to return.

We had the same items when it was Panda Country Kitchen and it was better and the portion of the cold dish items were much more generous.  Anyway, what we ordered:

Cold pork with garlic sauce - $4.89 - thin slices of pork belly with skin over a bed of julienne cucumber, drizzled with soy and garlic.  Very tasty - this was the best dish of the day.  

Spicy beef and tendon - $5.89 - thin slices of beef shank and tendon tossed in the numbing spicy oil.  Ok - the beef slices were very dry, tasted more like jerky.  Not spicy and missing a bit of flavor.

Pork and napa dumpling - $5.89 - 10 pieces served with a dish of dark vinegar on the side.  It's ok.

Spicy seafood noodle soup - $6.89 - it was not spicy.  The noodle was ok.  The best part of this dish is the fish, very flakey and sweet.  The shrimp was good too.  San Wang in J-town makes it better.

Every table had at least one large wok, which is their Happy Family dish.  We will have to try one.  Best to come with a lot of people so you can order many dishes to try and share.
author: Gloria H.

description:
Dong Bei Mama, where have you been all my 6 years of living in the bay area!??! 

The food here is so legit and authentic that when my picky parents from Hong Kong came to visit, I took them here, and they were *drum roll* very satisfied! 

Now my siblings and I come at least once a week. They have such a huge menu that we have not been able to try everything YET but here are some of our family faves: 

- Beef wrap roll (tastes like peking duck!) 
- Steamed tofu with fish (just like soy sauce steamed fish but this is fish fillets with tofu)
- Lamb hotpot with sour veggies and noodles 
- Potstickers 
- "water boiled" fish (ma la style)
author: Katherine C.

description: I'm only really judging based on the mapo tofu, but their version was kinda lackluster. Lots of cornstarch and not so much flavor. Other dishes might be better!
author: Jo B.

description:
Take out review! It's nice to have Chinese comfort food in our neighborhood for an insta-fix. The food is good, great for a weekday meal that doesn't break the bank and hits the spot. 

We had:

- Beef rolls - be prepared for a HUGE portion, really nice and doughy, tasty shank. 
- Steamed fish with tofu - I love a good Cantonese-style steamed fish with that sweet soy sauce and ginger/scallion combo. Super homestyle and made me very happy. 
- Salt and Pepper tofu - probably would stick to eating this in house next time. Very nicely salted, but it looses its crunch when you bring it home. 
- Preserved cabbage and lamb stew - very warming, glass noodles, that sourness of the cabbage, tender lamb slices, really great for cold weather. 

 It was about $20pp for our haul of food. 

Nicely done. If you can't get your Mama's cooking, this is a pretty good proxy.
author: Subie C.

description:
the Beef pancake is the best comfort food! I get this everytime I come. 
It also makes a great breakfast!
author: Juliana L.

description: I don't know what that alert in Yelp is, but this restaurant is very clean, the madam is so nice and we enjoyed the most wonderful dinner there in our last night at SF. If you want to taste the most delicious, true Chinese cooking, you definitely come and sit. I recommend anyone who visit SF to come here and enjoy the Chinese food.
author: Fang C.

description: The food was good, but the service was cold, I never heard they said "Thank you" every time I left the restaurant.
author: Shan S.

description: I was so disappointed with my meal at DongBei Mama. To be fair, I ordered to go and I had quite a drive home but that didn't change the flavor of the items I ordered. I got a beef pancake and a spicy beef noodle soup. The pancake was good enough. Massive. The dough was greasy and heavy, like a lead weight. The flavor of the items inside were good. The spicy soup was inedible. There was no flavor but spice and it had a big layer of oil that had floated to the top. Since the noodles and the broth were packed separately in my to go order, I first spooned out broth and "meat" into my bowl. Percentage-wise, the meat-like items were 80% gristle, fat, and other non meat chunks and 20% beef (which was quite delicious). Wish I took a picture of the gross carnage of blobs of gross. The noodles had been cooked too long and had no bite to them at all. Mushy. Yuck. After eating the innards of the beef roll, I dumped the remainder of everything else in the garbage. I'm shocked that the restaurant was a full when I got there. I will not be going back.
author: Debbie M.

description: This hole in the wall restaurant is a typical example of how it's great to find something authentic from Northern Chinese cuisine. Run by a group of Mandarin speaking employees, it would be rather difficult to explore your food options through verbal recommendations,so definitely consult the pictures on yelp!
author: Gordon D.

description: The giant meat pancake roll thing was 99% dough and no meat (if they made the pancake thinner it would have worked).. the shanghai dumplings were weak.  spicy beef soup lacked body.  food was not impressive - we didn't come close to finishing it and we had no desire to take leftovers home.  service was fast.
author: reza n.

description:
Today was my third visit to this place. Their good Northern Chinese food kept bringing me back here with different groups of friends. It's best to come in group, so you can try a bunch of dishes here. 

My #1 favorite dish is Preserved napa with pork belly or spare ribs. It's a very comforting dish and reminds me of a home-cooked dish (although my mom doesn't cook). I love the sour taste from the preserved napa which is mixed well with the broth. I've had this dish every time I came here. 

Other dishes to try include Dong Bei pork, Salt and Pepper Tofu, Scallion pancakes, etc. Fried rice with salty fish and chicken is also good here. 

I love the food here and will come back for more.
author: Saran R.

description:
Good, cheap Chinese food. Yum. I'm not sure what type of Chinese food it is, but my friends say it's probably closest to northern cuisine.

This place is great, and the prices are so cheap (roughly $7-12/dish depending on the meat). All the times I went, it's never busy and I was seated immediately--even with parties of 10. I think between 6 people, each person only paid $8-9? According to the boyfriend, who goes a lot with his family for dinner, it's never packed so if you're in the Richmond and you've got a hankering for Chinese and don't wanna wait in line, try this place out! Service is really nice here; it's always this one lady that takes our order (and I think it's because she's the only one who speaks English).

Beef pancakes: HUGE, and usually comes cut into about 6-8 pieces depending on how big they decide to make it.
Cold spicy chicken: This is under the cold dishes/appetizers section. It's okay as a chicken dish (could be better cooked), but the spicy sauce really makes it shine.
Local flavor lamb: They cook it well so that it's not too gamey. Comes with a bunch of veggies too, and some jalapeno slices are tossed in when they stir-fry it (I assume that's how it's made) so it has a little kick to it.
Sweet and sour fish: I'm not sure if that's the right name, but this dish is AMAZING. I don't like fish very much (it's either sashimi or it's got to be fried for me to eat it), but this is so good. The fish filets seem to be beer battered (or something similar) then tossed in the sweet and sour sauce--yum! Eat it quick because if you let it sit, the fried coating does get soggy. One friend said the fish reminded her of orange chicken--not very accurate, but it's ballpark. Definitely not as sour though.
Dry fried string beans: The string beans spent a littttttle too much time in the wok, if you know what I mean, But other than that, tasty and garlic-y.

Will I be back? Oh yes.
author: Doris K.

description: I came for a quick bite of something spicy- got Kung pao chicken and it's good- no complaints and the price seems good also-
author: Noah H.

description:
No wonder this place was empty when we came here. I had high hopes for this establishment but I should have followed my gut when the place was practically empty and the waiters were standing around playing games on their phones.

We had the option to choose our table, obviously and we decided to sit near the other 2 tables that were occupied in order make ourselves feel better about choosing this place and also to spy on their tables to see what they ordered. 

So we ordered the following, spicy pig ears(it was ok), black bean noodles(horrible as the noodles were cold), shanghai dumplings(the skin fell apart right when you picked it up) and the best dish we had which was bitter melon with scrambled eggs.

Food Highlight: Sadly, a dish you could easily make at home, the bitter melon with scrambled eggs.
author: Rich L.

description:
As far as I can tell, this is the only legitimate non-Cantonese Chinese place in SF!  They focus on styles from all parts of China but based on the name, their specialty is Northern Chinese.

Rockstar place for authentic cuisine as well as more Western-friendly foods.  The portions are huge and it really has one of the best prices in the city.  

Beef Rolls is a stand out dish as well as any of the big dishes with Broth.
author: Aaron R.

description: Overall food is just okay, although there are large portions.  However the beef roll is easily 5 stars.  Great combination with the cucumbers, and quite large.  I wish I could just buy this from a food truck and skip the main dishes.
author: Tiffany C.

description: This place is sorta hit-or-miss. However, the Twice Cooked Pork is fucking  fantastic!
author: Benjamin S.

description:
Absolutely LOVE this place. If anyone is looking for authentic Chinese food (much of which happens to be vegan) this is the place. I come here once a week pretty much without fail. The salt and pepper tofu is quite possibly the best tofu that I have ever had. It's crispy on the outside, silken on the inside, and a simple dish yet with complex flavor. I also love the veggie dumplings and string beans. The staff is also really great and friendly. Lastly portions are huge for the price so you can be sure there will be a lot of leftovers. 

My boyfriend is from Northern China and he says this is the best Chinese food that he's had in America.
author: Sarah S.

description: Best Chinese food restaurant ever! Can't miss this if ur in San Fran! Price reasonable, nice environment, with top service!
author: Katie H.

description:
I like this place for its chinese comfort food. skip the dumplings -- not juicy enough, the skin is a bit tough and dry. but these are the one that are done well:

napa cabbage and mushroom
dried tofu with chives
fish fillet with tofu in spicy sauce

But I do have to warn you that I did find a long black hair in one of the dishes (usually I am disgusted by this, but wasn't so this time). So this is definitely not for the faint-hearted...
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Authentic Chinese food from the Dong Bei and Sichuan region. It's no frills with the decor and atmosphere but very serious about the food.

I recommend the beef roll which is basically a fried dough with beef, cilantro, and peking duck sauce. I also liked the lamb and napa cabbage stew. The sliced pork ear is okay if you're willing to be adventerous -- it really doesn't taste weird or anything, just a bit oily. 

The dumplings are pretty par for the course and aren't anything to brag about. The Dongbei fried pork is sweet and is hard to eat a lot of but certainly is different.
author: Victor W.

description:
I'm ashamed to admit that I have two white friends who are way more Chinese than I'll ever be.  Both of them have lived in China for at least a year, and both of them can read more Chinese than I can.

But it's okay, because I still have the black hair and slanty eyes.  Booyah.

One of my friends wanted some good Sichuan food, and after I read Lolia's review of Dong Bei Mama, I knew I wanted to try.  So we headed out there, found parking no problemo on a Saturday around 5:30, and sat and ordered: Ma Po Tofu, Twice-cooked Pork Belly, and Pan-Fried Pork Bun.

At first we didn't know if this would be enough food, but the lady told us that the portions were large.  And large they were - we couldn't even finish everything.  The stuff is clearly meant to be shared, because I wouldn't have been able to eat the huge bowl of tofu myself, despite it being nice, spicy and delicious.

The pork belly, though spicy, wasn't the best I've had because it lacked a certain tenderness or something; I can't really figure out why I didn't like it very much.  I liked the pan-fried pork bun (imagine a regular bao, but pan-fried on the bottom to give it a crust), but since we had two each, it was too filling.  The filling was juicy and flavorful, and the bread on the outside was soft.

3.5 stars rounded up, because while their food wasn't the greatest, it wasn't bad either.  We figured that we just ordered the wrong things - clearly Sichuan food isn't their specialty.  Definitely will be back to try other things on the menu.

Oh and hi, they take credit cards with a $20 minimum.  That alone earns it the extra half star.
author: Tori S.

description:
We got our food to-go:

- Shrimp chives and pork dumplings: very good, nothing to complain.
- Chong Qing spicy chicken wings: crispy, spicy, very tasty. However, I'm just picky that they chopped up the chicken wings into "bite-size" pieces. The bones were all broken up and turned into these spears that stabbed the inside of my mouth. I wish they would just leave the wings as whole wings. 
- Honey walnut shrimps: one of the best honey walnut shrimps I've had. Shrimps were not soggy and it wasn't doused in mayo. The walnuts were clean and crisp, not soggy. 
- Sliced beef pancakes: it's a deep-fried beef wrap. Delicious.
author: LeTran B.

description:
I'm happy to see that a good restaurant has taken the place of Panda Country Kitchen (which I really liked and will miss). DB Mama has an extensive menu including a page of appetizers, a page of Sichuan specialties, iron platters, noodle soups, stews, clay pots, etc. They don't shy away from pork blood or intestines. The cold appetizers that they had at the back looked fantastic. The flour pancake rolled around sliced beef looked amazing (saw it after we ordered).

The clientele is mainly Chinese. It's a large space with huge tables (and smaller ones). Every table seemed to have a hot pot or some type of casserole over an open flame. Dongbei cuisine is known for hot pots, dumplings, and buns.

* Local flavor lamb: Thin, large pieces of tender lamb sautéed with huge jalapeno pieces, peppers, onions, had a lot of flavor, a little spicy, a bit too salty but tasty

* Happy family with fish ($13.89): I haven't seen these corn cake casseroles (a Dongbei dish) on the menu for a long time and I'm still a fan. This one features a light, bubbling broth with a whole fish, chunks of soft tofu in wok placed over a burner. The corn cakes (like man tou only made with corn meal) are on a separate plate. The fish is tender and mild. The stew looks bland but it's a nice, homey dish. The corn cakes were on the small side and not as good as the ones I had before.

* Beijing yogurt drink ($2.50) - a thick yogurt drink, tart but with a bit of sweetness, so good, love having this with a meal. The poster showed 3 flavors but they only had one flavor (regular/original).

$20 credit card minimum
author: Lolia S.

description:
Everytime I pass by Dong Bei Mama there's always a tour bus which got me thinking is this place THAT good? After a day at the beach we couldn't think of any place to eat for dinner and wanted to go somewhere close so we decided to go to here since it was really close by. It was quite a pleasant surprise. The food was good, price wasn't too expensive and the portions were huge enough that we had to take some food home. 

Recommended dishes:

Beef pancake
ma po tofu
spicy beef noodle soup (little too oily but the flavor was YUM!)
author: Elsa Y.

description:
Great local spot. Stumbled upon it when we found out My Tofu House was closed for the day.

We ordered the veghead staples: Kung Pao Tofu, Veg Chao Mein, and Sechzeuan (spell) style green beans.

They were all prepared well and quickly. Tea was solid too.

Only knocks: food a tad on the greasy side and it was not seasoned or as spicy as much as we'd have preferred. Not enough to knock more than a star though.

Friendly staff. Quick service.
author: A.J. T.

description: Great people that work here. Portions are great . Pricing is more then reasonable . I have been here 3 times this month for lunch and dinner . Kung Pow tofu rocks
author: William W.

description:
Yumm. Service was awesome and food was great. Traffic was awful getting out of the city so needed a place to eat. A good call for locals or hungry drivers heading north! 

Beef and onions delicious!
author: Tracy M.

description:
Came back after Jon Kaufmann's glowing review.

We tried the Five spices pig head, which is like a terrine served with julienned cucumbers and a sort of vinegarette. This was a very nice cold starter.

The sizzling cumin lamb was a miss, came out too saucy and not enough cumin flavor. Mission Chinese food and Z&Y do this dish proper.

The chicken and salt fish hot pot was nice, served with tofu. It could have used some scallions as garnish though.

We wanted to try one of the Dong Bei specialties and went with the Dong Bei fried pork. However, it  came out with a sweet batter that we didn't like.

Our favorite dish was the Chong Qing chicken wings, a Sichuan dish leftover from the previous menu of Panda Country Kitchen. This was really spicy and numbing from the Sichuan peppercorns. Probably one of the best renditions I've had.

The menu is huge, so still lots to try. I'd probably try more of the Sichuan part of the menu though next time, as I never had Panda Country Kitchen's fare.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I came here again because the first time the food was okay. I thought the beef pancake was good...

This time we ordered the Crunchy or Cripsy Lamb and the spicy fish thing.
The food was COLD and OILY.

The lamb was smacked paper thin and was somehow too rubbery to even try to chew through. And it is supposedly Fried, so I am at a lost as to why it came COLD.

The fish was oily and cold as well... And I didn't like that it was served over bean sprouts rather than napa cabbage.

The food seemed to be old and barely even reheated. Disgusting

Please don't come here because the reviews are misleading.
author: Nona T.

description: This the best Chinese food I have ever had. Beef Pancake is the best one: everyone should order one! It is very close Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Albert C.

description:
Mid-priced Chinese with a strong emphasis on regional Manchurian food. 

My biggest complaint about Chinese restaurants generally is how little variation there is from Sichuan standards (often prepared indifferently).  Unless you can order off-menu, you'd never know that it is one of the the most refined and varied cuisines in the history of humanity from the average menu. Not here!

Yes, there are some Sichuan dishes, and generally well prepared. But the Dong Bei food is the standout. The cold plates have all been good, as are the dumplings, noodles and stews. The vegetables don't get short shrift (I'm not a vegetarian, but I can really tell when a place is phoning it in with the veggies, and if you don't treat your veggies well, it shows up everywhere).

I haven't liked everything I've gotten there, but every chance has felt worth the effort. It has literally been decades since I've has so many pleasant surprises at a Chinese restaurant.
author: Stefan A.

description:
Din. Food: 3/5
Chicken chow mein. 3. But couldn't stop eating!
Lamb dumplings. 3
Salt and pepper tofu: 3.5. Yum but very little tofu content? 
Way too much food for 2. $34 post tip and 1 beer. 
Get beef pancake next time.
author: Olivia Q.

description: Used to live around the block from this place. Didn't ever go in because after hours pet control was trying to capture a raccoon in there. Not for me. But as for the busloads of Chinese tourists who come in, it seems to be good. Seriously, this place must have some deal with the tour buses that serve Chinese folks. Question is: did the raccoon know too much about this sketchy partnership?
author: Nancy D.

description:
I don't know how to feel about this place. I've been here several times and every time while the food taste alright it just never seems to leave me a happy person after I'm done eating.
While I appriciate food coming out quickly, there is also something to be said for food that comes out in 5 minutes when the menu has 100 or 200 options. There are so many options that they can't just number the food they have to give it a letter and a number to identify the dish.
author: Cescilia A.

description:
cabage and lamb pot was good
tofu and fish was good
si gua was good
author: Diane W.

description:
This was my first time visiting the restaurant. I read the reviews and was very excited to try it out. I was dining by myself and didn't expect it to be an issue, but when I got there they didn't have any room. 

I was asked to share a table with a couple, which I gladly did, and they were very nice. The menu is fairly easy to understand with lots of pictures. I am a vegetarian, and there were lots of veggie choices so that was good.

I ordered the moha tofu, which I thought would be a bit spicy. The food came out pretty fast, and the portions are very large. My entree could have easily been consumed by a group of 4. 

Overall the food was good, and it had good flavor. I would come back again.
author: Raj K.

description: Super cheap, pretty decent szechuan food! Plus it opens until 3am.
author: Andy J.

description:
You come here not to impress but to chow down, Chinese homey style with friends and family. Came with a group of 7 after hiking and we were ready to eat!

Stuff we shared:
- beef pancake wrap. Excellent. Big portion too. Liked it so much we got two orders. 
- beef noodle soup. Ok. 
- cold glass noodle in peanut sauce. Pretty tasty
- sizzling cumin lamb. I didn't have any but the guys who did really liked it. 
- pork cabbage casserole pot. This is a sharing kind with a table top gas burner. Lots mod tasty fatty pork pieces with sweet cabbage and glass noodles. 
- Green bean stir fry. Delish

Overall food was 3 stars but I gave 1 extra for the service. The waitress was so friendly and accommodating especially since we had a baby to contend with too. Deserves an extra star.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Dong Bei Mama definitely serves 100% genuine Chinese food.  Here we go-

1.  Cold platter (item 15?) is something that you would find in Northeastern China (Dong Bei).  Deliciously genuine.  $10.95
2.  Dan Dan Noodle- it is OK.  It's kind of oily.
4.  Beef Noodle Soup- Below average.  Once is enough.
5.  Beef Chow Fun- It's best to leave this dish to Cantonese chefs.  The chef couldn't duplicate the taste.
6.  Beef Pancake- 100% FIVE-STAR.  Strongly recommended.  It is equivalent to two jumbo burritos.  It is HUGE!  Fantastic!!!  YUMMY!!!
7.  Some kind of vegetable dish (Item 3?) with Enokitake.  Too sour for me.
8.  Sour fish and lamb soup with cabbage.  Guess what?  It is not sour enough for me.
9.  Basil clam dish.  Nah.  Cantonese chefs do it better.

Service- Fairly attentive.
Decor- Nice.  Lots of paintings.
Restroom- Fairly slippery.  It is a disaster waiting to happen.  Beware.
Speed of putting out dishes- Amazingly quick.  I like it.
Price/portion ratio (PPR)- This analysis rates Dong Bei Mama a BUY!
author: Food S.

description:
This place is great, especially if you can stand a little heat.  

One of the other posters said the food is oily, but I totally disagree - it just entirely depends on what you order, like any restaurant.  Now, almost everything is spicy, and a few things are head-exploding spicy, so be careful what you order.  The mapo tofu is great (although it had mushrooms instead of beef - bummer there) and so was a flaming hot fish dish with a name a can't recall (but my eyes are watering just thinking about it).
author: K C.

description:
Yum! While this restaurant won't win any awards for its decor, the food was pretty great. We got mixed mushrooms, eggplant with green pepper and potato, and kung pao tofu. They were all pretty tasty. The mixed mushrooms were my favorite.

Service was really friendly too! Go!
author: Tom Z.

description:
Something must be right about this restaurant if tour groups from China take their tourists here. That being said, this is probably not your joint if you just want to get your Kung Pao Chicken fix. 

We got a few pretty simple things such as napa and mushroom, pickled vegetable vermicelli soup, pork belly and bamboos shoots.  It reminds me of being a youngster going to Chinese potluck and eating someone's moms food. It's authentic, good, and felt varied.  Unlike a lot of Chinese restaurants, the people speak mandarin there not cantonese (feels homier personally). For those who don't like sweet Chinese food, as for as I could taste this place doesn't arbitrarily try to sweeten things.  

Like many chinese restaurants, this place is good for groups. Several large tables with lazy susans.
author: Dian X.

description: Continued to enjoy the fried intestine and crispy lamb.  The menu/cooking has changed a bit in the past 3 years though.  I miss the old days.
author: Drew B.

description:
I am shocked by all of the 4 and 5 star ratings. Have you people never eaten good Chinese food? We ordered Dong Bei Mama thru waiter.com for lunch and everyone who ordered it, was unhappy. I got the beef and broccoli which was bland. The broccoli was soggy and the meat chewy. My co-worker got the a fried a spicy chicken and it was atrocious. I've never tasted worse Chinese food in my life. 

Perhaps the food is better fresh at the restaurant, but I would recommend you stay far away from this place.
author: Adam B.

description:
Food = AMAZING! 
Service = TERRIBLE!!!!

Let's talk about the good first! My family and I ordered: (sorry forgot the numbers!)
Sliced Beef Pan Cake: MY FAVORITE DISH!! DEFINITELY RECOMMEND!!! I first tried it at the other restaurant and it was soo good! and still good! Enough meat and leeks with Hoi Seen Sauce! SO DELICIOUS!! You won't be disappointed!
Lamb Dumpling: My favorite dumpling out of Pork, Shrimp, and Veggie dumpling. Lamb was juicy and flavorful. Pork was boring. Shrimp was different, Veggie did not surprise me at all.
Da Lu Noodle. It was good. The soup was delicious and enough veggies to split for four.
Pan Fried Pork Bun: These buns were FATTY! Nothing too special, but it was satisfying! I won't recommend this since you can get buns any where!
Pork Cake and Beef Cake: Not much flavor, I had to add vinegar to have the kick for this dish. You be the judge if you want to order it or not.

Service wise... Now, I've been to the other location, terrible service... so, I was hoping service would be good... nope, exactly same people and terrible service. Waitress ignore you and give you attitude -- screams at you, "what do you want?" ... uhmm we politely asked you for boxes... you didn't give us any and we're politely asking you the second time.

If it wasn't for the sliced beef pan cake... I would not come here! But, I'm in love with the sliced beef pan cake! sigh!
author: Lianne D.

description: The beef pancake is deeelicious, the ma po tofu will set your caucasian alimentary tract on fire, and everything else I've had has been good. It seems to be a popular spot on the chinese tour group circuit, but they have plenty of big tables, and are very efficient, so it doesn't seem to cause any traffic jams.
author: Kristina B.

description: Super suspicious when we walked in on a Saturday night and the place was empty except for two tables. Spicy boiling fish was acceptable and smoked pork with garlic leaves was good but too salty for me. Ignore all reviews raving about "best beef pancake" unless you enjoy dry, tasteless "beef" wrapped in thick flavorless dough. The dumplings (xiao long bao) were big dry balls of meat, better off buying frozen dumplings from Ranch 99. Awful.
author: Audrey T.

description: Excellent food, big portions. Inexpensive. Salt and pepper tofu, dry wok beef, cold potato app, beef pancake all get top reviews. For Chinese by Chinese but happy to sneak in
author: J D.

description: Beef Pancake Roll is a must order.  Tea Smoked Duck was solid.
author: Jim S.

description:
My bf and I are regulars - we actively try not to go there because we eat there too much. The food we order always comes out very hot and full of flavor. We're

Favorite Dishes: Salt and Pepper Tofu; Szechuan Eggplant; Saute String bean; Snow Pea Leaf; Tofu and Ginger Soup. #vegetarian

For those who gave bad reviews about the language barrier, we've never had a problem, even when we've asked for some special requests. A little patience goes a long way.  We also know to point to things on the menu as a courtesy (waiters/tresses get stressed out too!).

Service is always super friendly. I suggest going at dinner time when the restaurant is less busy - tour buses dine at the restaurant during lunch, so it gets pretty full.
author: Anna H.

description:
Beef pancakes! Don't get the xiao long bao though, the skin is too thick and the insides aren't juicy and tender. =\

Other than that, it's just an average Taiwanese/Chinese food place that's a bit pricier than what you can normally find in SF. Their soup noodles are loaded with MSG, while their fried rice's taste fluctuates (depends on the chef's mood, eh?). Service is a hit or miss as well - either they serve you pretty efficiently, or it takes forever + a day to flag down a waiter.
author: Charmian W.

description:
This is a must try.....for spicy lovers.....

We ordered pork belly clear noodle soup that comes with thinly chopped napa cabbage soup.....great

Scallion pancake rolled with five spice beef with hoisin sauce and parsley...not spicy, my favorite....

Beef pancakes, very good.....

Fried spicy spareribs, very very good, this is my other favorite.....

Fried frog.....too spicy for me but all others loved it....

Fried chicken wings...incredibly spicy....

Pork belly with leeks, my 3rd favorite ......

Sing gwa veggies, I have no idea what this is called in English so go with my description....

I know what u are thinking, so much fried food, yes, and very spicy, we ordered way too much for 5 of us.....so order less....everything goes well with rice or plain noodles.....
author: Leslie Y.

description: Great high-volume place. On tour bus rotation, but that's probably a good thing in this case because the food has been fresh and well done. Beef pancakes are the best I've had, and they will sure fill you up! Other items have also been good. Service decent, parking is available fairly easily around this stretch of Geary,
author: T J.

description: Food is freshly prepared and tasty.  We love the pea shoots, spicy fish, and spicy tripe.  We usually pick up instead of eating there.  The place looks very clean.  The other night when I came by to pick up, a large group was having dinner.  Two young male Chinese workers were at the back wall, hanging out.  One was busy picking away at his nose, even when I walked in to say I was here for a pick up.  The other went to put together my order while the nose-picking guy looked at me and kept cleaning his nose.  I was relieved that he wasn't the one to go get my food.  Needless to say, I was disgusted.  He stopped picking his nose after a minute or so but that pretty much did it for me.  Boogers = one star penalty.
author: G K.

description:
I hate to say it but this place may be too real for my ABC palate. My mom ordered this sour napa and lamb stew that was just too intense for me. I really couldn't get in to it. We also ordered mala cold noodles that were just mala and not really seasame-ey or peanuty which I also couldn't get in to.

I did enjoy our beef sha bing, good flakey dough and a pretty generous portion. The 5 spice pig head appetizer was great too.
author: Misha T.

description:
The beef pancake was amazing. Everyone loved it. I don't eat beef, and picked that out, and I thought it was super delicious!

We also got the tofu and bok Choy hot pot soup which was okay.  Very bland.  Wouldn't get that again,  huge portion, tho.

We also ordered the stir fry string beans and they were good.

This must be a stop for a tour bus because at 11:30 am about 40 people came in at once.  Glad we had ordered our food prior to them arriving.  It was a bit of an effort to get our bill and food wrapped up to go.

We walked here from the de Young after enjoying the David Hockney exhibit and seeing Elizabeth Taylor's jewelry.

The weather was amazing and views around sf so perfect.  Taking the elevator up the tower at de young was free and the views today were so clear. We could see the ocean.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Avg. food.  Beef stuffed scallion cake probably the only good dish there.
author: Xiaoming F.

description: Food was delicious. Especially the spicy sauce fish filets & seafood over sizzling rice.  Service was quick and efficient. If you're into it, tangy black fungus appetizer was good too.
author: Carl C.

description: This place is pretty hit or miss - sometime's the food is fantastic, other times just OK. But I'm giving it an extra star because the service is good and it's the only place I've found in San Francisco that serves guobaorou (fried pork in a ginger-based sauce of yummy goodness). The food--on it's on days--is pretty authentic dongbei Chinese food (I know because I lived in Liaoning province for two years). Go with a bunch of people and order a variety of dishes to get the most out of your experience.
author: Allison P.

description: This place is awesome. Been trying to find authentic Dongbei food for 2 years. This is it!  Definitely buy the Preserved Napa with pork belly and the sliced beef pancakes. Also their dumplings are the best authentic dumplings in the city. The service is nice and the owner Kelly is really great! We will be coming back often.
author: Craig P.

description: Amazing value for the food. Green beans with smoked pork: flavor was deep, not too greasy. Beef roll was surprisingly light and not greasy as well. Steamed fish and tofu with soy sauce was delicious. Texture was nice and soft, flavor was subtle with ginger and scallion. Highly recommend coming here.
author: Alvin W.

description: this review is just for carryout, since i've never actually had a proper sit down meal here.  that said, the food is absolutely wonderful! my favorite is the beef pancakes.
author: Miiiiiiiiike S.

description:
