The best Chinese food I've yet had in the city.  (Mission Chinese and San Tung sit pouting in the corner)

We went out with my boyfriend's Chinese family and thus ordered an insane amount of food.  Pretty much everything was a highlight but let me break it down.

TO GET:

The beef scallion wrap: as good as everyone says.  Dough is crispy and buttery, meat is tender and flavorful and the cilantro and cucumber it is all wrapped around add a unique freshness to it.

The Chow Fun: wide slippery noodles with a TON of carmelized onions make it so so savory

The green beans: The best I've ever had (at a restaurant--boyfriend's chinese family is the only time I've seen it done better).  They are garlicky and crisp--still have remnants of the vegetable they were before they got fried.  They are also coated in something like black bean that adds a punch

Lamb dumplings: they are very LAMB-Y so be prepared for that.  If you like a bit of gamey-ness you'll love these.  They are really juicy.  Almost like a xiao long bao (XLB as the cool kids say)

Twice cooked pork belly- boyf says this was the best dish on the table but I'm not in to pork so you can make your mind up as to whether you trust him or not.


THINGS THAT WERE GOOD BUT YOU COULD STILL LIVE A FULFILLING LIFE WITHOUT TRYING:

The scallion pancake was good but just fried dough.  Nothing to write home about

The lamb stew.  Too spicy for my liking.  Came with lots of veggies which I liked but it just didn't change my life.  Plus it's hard to eat because of those looooooong translucent noodles that whip at your wrists, scalding you as you try to serve yourself and look cool in front of your boyfriend's chinese family.

I am trying to think up an excuse to go back there immediately.  Luckily portions were enormous so we have tons of leftovers.  Also I peeked at the bill and it was so so reasonable.
author: Meg M.

description:
The first time I came, my friend recommended the preserved cabbage with pork belly soup.  It was an interesting taste.  Sour, but yet pleasant, taste.  I wasn't excited about the pork belly, though.  I mainly stuck to the cabbage and the clear noodles that were underneath the pot.

For about $8, that soup came out in a freaking wok!  I was surprised how big it was!  It can easily serve me for another 5 meals!  We also ordered the shrimp fried rice (which tasted pretty normal and nothing special) and the spicy meat dish for appetizer.  It didn't give me the numbness I was expecting for as I get from other Szcheun restaurants.  Well, I guess this isn't that type of restaurant, so I don't blame them. 

Second time I came, ordered the soup again....just wasn't sitting in well.  Also ordered the green onion pancake (too much dough and flour, and not enough green onions and taste), and the spicy fish.  I definitely got he spicy numbness from that dish!  Taste was good, but texture, eh.  Too much cornstarch.  I felt like I was eating a bowl of cornstarch.  

After the meal, I felt uneasy.  Not sure if it was just my hangover or just the food.
author: Nancy S.

description:
Coming out of my "Yelp-review-writing-boycott" after being de-Elited.  Yes, after 5 consistent year's Yelp de-Elited me.  Note: I was pretty much the only Asian where I was previously living, so had to go into hiding--writing anything but nice reviews was difficult.

BUT, Dong Bei Mama is just too good not to get a rave review.  Stumbled in here on a Sunday evening for dinner.  There were already several parties at 7pm, but by 7:30pm just about a full house.

Enjoyed:
-Cold spicy pig ears + cold spice beef tendon & beef: if you like the numbing flavor of sichuan peppercorns, these are your dishes to order!  While there still was oil, it seemed like somehow they dialed back the oiliness, almost as if it was thickened somehow.
-Beef onion pancake: One family had the right idea to get two orders!  While the pancake I thought could have been a tad thinner, it was quite flavorful.
-Smoked pork belly w/ garlic leaves: The standout dish of the meal! Smoky and great flavors.  Could have fooled me--the supposed garlic leaves seemed like leeks.  Nevertheless would order this again!
-Dry fried green beans: Interesting twist on what I'm used too--these ones had fermented black beans.  Delicious!
-Spicy whole fish (catfish): Our least favorite of the meal.  Unfortunately it came out more "warm" than piping hot.  Felt like the value wasn't there for the money either.

I think we even met the Dong Bei Mama with her bright dyed hair.  She was super friendly and seemed to accept my broken Mandarin.  That in itself made me a bigger fan!
author: Christopher W.

description:
The food was great, and the service was incredible! I had the Beef Pancake (must-have), hot and sour soup (pretty good), and a spicy fish dish which was bursting with flavor and heat. 

More importantly, and the whole reason I'm writing a review, is that a woman, who I can only assume was the owner, was unbelievably friendly. She noticed how much time we were spending with the menu and came and made several recommendations, asking us what types of food we like, giving estimates on portions and how much we should order, and was very genuine about wanting us to really enjoy our meal. Even if the meal wasn't excellent, I would've rated 5 stars on this alone, but the food was worth returning for of it's own accord.
author: Robert F.

description:
This used to be Panda Country House or Country Panda House or something. Right?

The food is delicious Northern Chinese style with lots of dumplings, noodles, and flatbreads. They have the beef rolls. They have the cold yam noodle appetizer. 

They also have an amazing cache of tourists from China who get trucked in nonstop for lunch at noon. 

Hey, if the Chinese tourists from China like this place....
author: May T.

description:
You'll notice that everyone here is talking about the sliced beef pancake roll. That's because it's legit. It's the size of my arm and delicious. It's like a sandwich wrap filled with fresh onions and thin slices of beef. Do yourself a favor and order this. Thanks mama.

My tummy gives Dong Bei Mama...4 Stars!
author: Allan L.

description: Love this place. So good and cheap. Came here for Lunar new year dinner and it was $13 per person for a dozen of us. We had seafood soup, two orders of dumplings, noodle dishes, veggies, tofu and beef/scallion pancake. Came here once before and it was also very good. Helps to have Chinese-speaking friends when you come here who know what to order...
author: Xteethx B.

description:
The beef pancake roll is indeed delicious, as is the fish and tofu in spicy sauce.  They have a young bamboo braised in oil that's really great, not too spicy and delightfully flavorful.  The Dalu noodles are nothing to write home about, but alright.  The shrimp fried rice wrapped in lotus leaves is homey - filling and comforting with lots of peas and a light splash of eggs.  

All the northern Chinese immigrants and tourists in San Francisco seem to know and frequent this place.  It's one of the few Chinese places in the city where speaking Cantonese is not a local status symbol, and mandarin of various northern accents can be heard.

The bathroom is clean, and doubles as a storage area for extra tables and chairs.

I'm really charmed by how the restaurant's English and Chinese names work as a pair.  Dongbei mama's Chinese name is Country Bumpkin () - making it one of the few restaurants I can think of where the names represent two different genders yet connotes similar sentiments!
author: Di Yin L.

description:
The food itself is okay. Standard run of the mill Chinese food. Above average compared to most other Chinese places.

 I enjoyed the salted peppered rib more than I would. Most  restaurants sucks at cooking them.

The main thing I didn't like about the place was more spices/peppers than actual food (on the dishes we ordered) and the food itself was really oily. But to be fair, it is  part of the cooking style so..... But still......
author: Welmond C.

description: Great dishes for the winter, especially the various cauldrons of veges and meats. Their cumin lamb is tasty. My wife did all of the ordering as she picked her favorites.
author: Tinyee H.

description:
Le sigh.....I had high hopes for this place but was quite disappointed. The only redeeming qualities about this place were the prices and the sour napa and lamb casserole.

HIT - The sour napa and lamb casserole is one of my favorite chinese dishes and they made this one very well. Quite delish!

Sadly, nothing else was good.

MISS - dan dan noodles - off the menu but the waiter said the kitchen can make it. Naturally, we got super excited.  The noodles had the "ma la" chili that completely numbed my mouth making me unable to taste anything else. I do NOT recommend this. No warning from waiter either!

MISS - Xiao Long Bao - Is it possible to have bad  XLB? Yes. and it's in Dong Bei Mama

MISS - potato eggplant and green bellpepper. Lots of superfluous sauce  - nothing remarkable. Tasted like takeout from your typical neighborhood bad Chinese food street corner restaurant called King of Hunan or Hunan Flavor Delight. 

Overall not a good dining experience. Food was comme ci comme ca. Waiter forgot our order of XLB. I was not able to enjoy our food because my tongue was numb and I also left with a numb tongue. 

I will say this though, there were many other items on the menu that looked promising so I wont write this place off entirely. I guess you just need to know what to order. But wouldn't you rather go to a restaurant where everything was good?
author: Jo-Ann L.

description:
Good portions, authentic Chinese food. Spicy actually means spicy.
Beef pancake is fried on the outside.
author: Christian E.

description:
Pretty good overall.  Got the slice beef pancake, green beans, chongqing chicken wing chunks and spicy water boiled fish (northern rather than true Sichuan)
The beef pancake was very fresh with lots of goodness and not too much hoisin, large dish, not too much oil
The spicy chicken bone-in with chilies was done pretty well, nice and spicy
Fish was ok.  Would try the beef cakes next time
author: Rob C.

description:
To enjoy this place one must understand that sichuan peppers will leave a numbing tingling sensation. With that in mind come enjoy a place that does hit the spot for that.

This Chinese restaurant has quickly vaulted up to be one of my favorites in San Francisco. Some favorite dishes of mines have been the fillet fish and their beef pancake roll. For me though i don't even bother picking, i let my friends pick because everything I've had here I've enjoyed. 

  Be careful because for some people this place is pretty spicy but if spice is what you love this is a great destination for you.
author: John T.

description:
great Chinese/Sichuan food, definitely one of the better ones in the City.  We come here mainly for the BF's favorite dish: the sichuan fish filet dish - filet fish soaked in hot, spicy sichuan sauces. We usually just order it to go. I bring a tupperware for the to-go order and they are very accommodating.   It's also very well-priced-most dishes range from $9-$14 each, and portions are family-size!

They look like they have great appetizer dishes (like those cold sesame seaweed).

A lot of tour buses drop off the tourists here to eat as well.  Always a great sign if they continue to bring Chinese tourists here to eat!
author: Connie H.

description:
I came here in a group of 7 for a Saturday night dinner. I somehow managed to be the only non-Chinese person in the group so I let the others order a bunch of dishes, and what a great job they did!

We got the sizzling platter cumin lamb, green beans, a hot pot with cubes of delicious pork belly, a slightly tart (but yummy) soup, pork buns, a beef wrapped in roti-like bread dish, and spicy sauteed tofu with pork.  Apologies for not knowing the actual dish names. I literally browsed through menu and as I heard my friends talking about dishes, I basically put the menu down and let them have at it.

The point is, the dishes we got were all very flavorful and delicious.  The beef wrapped in pancake/roti-like bread was awesome.  The pork belly chunks in the hot pot were also delicious.  I pretty much could eat any of those dishes again, if only what they were actually called.  The sauteed tofu/pork was a little bit spicy (I was worried it'd burn my tongue off, but I was ok). 

Minus one star for the flavorless cornbread like muffins that came with the soup and the buns for having a high bun to filling ratio.  Overall though, the food was good and I left happy (and full!).  The whole meal cost us only $13.50 each.  A steal!!

I like that this restaurant specializes in more northern Chinese food, so I actually got to try completely new dishes this time.  I hope to come back!
author: Naoko M.

description: As I am writing this, I am also eating their delicious food. BUT I AM PISSED!  I know at the end of the day you may run low on certain things, but giving me only half of the amount from the usual, not tell me about it, and charges me the full amount is just not right. It's happened multiple of times already. At least give me something small to make up for it if you're going to charge me the full amount. It's like paying full price for a shirt and my nipples are fully exposed!!!
author: Jack L.

description:
You really can't go wrong with Dong Bei Mama. The price is moderate along with the quality of the food, and the selection is incredible. They have so many plates with just vegetables that I don't feel pressured to always eat meat here.

There's a good reason this place is packed with Chinese people at night.
author: Sterling D.

description:
I live maybe 40 steps away from Dong Bei Mama... yeah I live across the street from it.  And for months I hadn't even considered stepping foot into it.  I think it was the name that threw me off... if I don't know how to pronounce it or why there's a Mama in its name, I didn't think it was for me.

But on a whim, my parents visited me and decided to try some place close... yeah 40 steps close.  They speak very limited English here!  And even if you're Cantonese, you might as well just speak English to them here!  This is considered North Eastern Chinese food... in the region known as Manchuria.  The key here is to look at what everyone is ordering and if it looks good, ask your waiter what that is.  

The must order was the Sliced Beef Pancake Roll.  A large onion pancake spread with hoisin and rolled with sliced beef, cucumbers, and scallions!  It's a filler so share with a group of 4.  This region of China does not specialize in rice, so do not order fried rice or any rice dish here.  Their specialties are noodles and dumplings.  Also don't assume XLB or soup dumplings would be good here... that's Shanghai.  This region would do better with simple boiled dumplings -- pork w/ chives or pork w/ napa cabbage is the solid standby.  I'll have to try their pan fried dumplings soon!

Much of the tables had a casserole going on... mini stoves were set up in each table so you could serve your stewy soupy bits piping hot!  Manchuria is so far north, it definitely gets freezing there. So these stove dishes would be great for cold weather. 

if you are adventurous, step up to their corner counter that displays cold appetizers ranging from pickled daikon salad to pressed pork cheeks that looks look tiny stained glass windows with their clear offal parts and skin.  Everything here is so reasonable it'd be a loss to you if you didn't try whatever looked curious!  This region has clean flavors that are often spicy... nothing too stinky.  

If you come during lunchtime you may see bus loads of Chinese tourist filling up half of the large dining room.  When I was there it was very apparent they were from mainland China and they were so happy to see familiar food.  They ate fast and knew exactly what was what... a good sign of authenticity.
author: Chris T.

description:
Living next door to this place, I had the privilege to try many things on Panda Country Kitchen's and then Dong Bei Mama's menu, and by the time I moved it had become one of my favorite places to eat in the city.

If you like Sauerkraut, I think any of the Sour Napa dishes are great, from the Bean Noodle and Ground Pork to the Lamb Stew. It is quite sour, but also very flavorful, and reminds me of Polish food, in a good way.

I have to admit my favorite thing at Dong Bei Mama is still the Fish Fillet with Tofu in Spicy Sauce. It's on the Sichuan menu, and it's little more than steamed cod and tofu covered in chili oil, but the cod is really good and the tofu is really silky. I don't know. I can eat that thing every day.

I'd also recommend the Beef with Yam, Da Lu Noodle (soup), the Egg and Pepper Black Bean Noodle and the Spicy Noodle Cooked with Ground Pork Sauce (which I think was only on the Panda Country menu, but they still make it). They are all large portions best for sharing. 

I also love the Sauteed Singua, but fair warning... most of the menu is made Family Style and some dishes are just giant plates of one thing. (Beware the plate of shredded potato!) ....miss this place.
author: Zachary M.

description:
I by no means am an expert on Chinese food, nor am I that adventurous of an eater, but this place fell short for me - especially after seeing all of the rave reviews.

The servers are very nice, just not organized at all. Didn't understand my order, gave away one of our dishes, never brought white rice, and served us hot water instead of tea. I wasn't expecting Michelin starred service, but even the basics were missed here.

This place could be great for authentic Chinese, but certainly not American-ized Chinese. Avoid basic dishes like orange chicken and general cho's - just not their specialty. Also, and this is something that I have had a lot of experience eating, their Shanghai dumplings were soup-less, which to me misses the whole point of ordering that dish.

I just don't believe this place deserves 4 stars based on the quality of food and overall service. Maybe 3 at best, but I don't think I'll be returning.
author: John G.

description:
It's a decent place to grab Chinese food. Cheap and clean! I had the spinach with garlic. It was on the saltier side. Next time I will let them know. The sole was steamed a little bit too long but good flavors. My favorite were the steam shanghai mini buns. 
I would return and try other dishes.
author: M C.

description: Cuisine from my home town, I am an expert of Dongbei cuisine. I will say this restaurant is not perfect, but good enough for me to come again and again and bring many chinese friends here. I even have brought an american friend to try here, he loooooves the dishes! So I highly recommand here!
author: Pelou G.

description: Eat here 5 days in one week. Best chinese restaurant in San Francisco. Home food for me. Feels so good after eating!!!!
author: Tian C.

description:
Come here for the food. And for the surprisingly swift service. Not for the ambiance, of course, but then again when do you ever go to a Chinese restaurant for the ambiance?

The one dish alone that makes a trip here worth it is the sliced beef pancake roll. This is my absolute favorite dish -- no exaggeration. Technically it's a northern Chinese dish, but it's been popularized also in Taiwan. It consists of sliced spiced roast beef, green onions, cilantro, and hoisin sauce, all wrapped in a scallion pancake. I can't emphasize how tasty it is when it's done right. I also can't emphasize how difficult it is to find in the Bay Area. To my knowledge there isn't a single other restaurant in SF that serves it. You have to go down to San Mateo, Cupertino, or even Milpitas to find decently-made ones.

But the best part about the dish here is that, not only are the ingredients perfectly proportioned, but that the entire dish itself is HUGE. Typically it's served as an appetizer maybe to be split between 2 or 3 people. The one here though is more like a medium pizza -- even with a party of 6 I had to eat an extra slice and a half for us to finish the whole thing.

The rest of the dishes we ordered were delicious. We had Sichuan-style boiled fish and fried diced chicken, as well as sauteed pea pod sprouts, fatty pork with bok choy, and a clear rice noodle with veggies. All this we washed down with a couple bottles of Tsingtao.

Despite coming here on a busy night (the Saturday before CNY), our dishes came out incredibly fast. Still, one star off for just general slumminess of the place -- it's not to be mistaken for R&G Lounge, anyway.
author: Albert L.

description: The service was bad. The chicken mushroom that we ordered was not fresh, especially the chicken. we were super disappointed with the food and service. :/
author: Max S.

description:
Sliced beef pancake was GOOOOD. It's about the size of my face and could feed an entire hoard of Chinese tourists coming out of those huge tour buses (I have a big face, alright??) 

The pork belly and preserved napa cabbage soup was delicious! It was a good kind of tangy that hit the spot on a very cold day. If you cannot handle a lot of pork belly, then this dish is probably not for you. The glass noodles were a nice addition. I don't know if it was just me or if I'm ladle-challenged, but I had the HARDEST TIME getting the noodles in my bowl. Right as I was getting a good chunk of noodles in my bowl, it would plop back into the hot pot. Or onto the table. WHAT IS YOUR SECRET, PEOPLES?! For every 10 noodles I scooped out of the pot, two successfully made it into my bowl. The rest had to be sacrificed for the good of the others D:

Other than that, I had a very satisfying lunch that came out to a reasonable price.
author: Moraia W.

description:
PLEASE COME HERE.  YOUR STOMACH WILL REALLY THANK YOU FOR IT!

Now, let me preface that the things I love here are not your run-of-the-mill Chinese food.  This is not the place I go if I feel like chow mein, chow fun, and xiao long bao dumplings.  This is definitely more like regional food for me that's wonderful, made-by-a-Chinese-Mama-from-Dong-Bei, and full of spicy goodness!

If it's your first time, I suggest coming with a group.  Portions are generous and it's nice to share and try a bunch of things out.  

Favs:
*Beef pancake roll- The best, but simplified description is like a delicious green onion pancake roulade with dried/cured beef, cilantro, and onions.  DELICIOUS AND MASSIVE!

*Pork, pickled cabbage, sour soup- VERY REGIONAL AND VERY DELICIOUS!  It's served in a huge pot on a burner and comes piping hot!  So good.

Simple dishes that were just done really well:
*Baked tofu with chives
*Mapo Tofu- probably one of the best I've had in awhile.

Misses:
*Eggplant and potato dish- It was sweet and sour and had some fried pieces.  Apparently very regional, but a bit odd for my tastebuds and unfortunately was a VERY LARGE serving.

I would say that if you're in the mood for Chinese, but want something a bit more flavorful and spicy then this is a great place to check out!  

Parking is not fun in this area, but we were seated quickly on a Friday night for 7 people.  The food came out super fast and our waiters/tresses were great!  They even threw in a free green onion pancake (probably since we went to town ordering that night), but they've always been great when I've gone.

Let this Dong Bei Mama take care of you!
author: Christine K.

description:
best chinese food in the city.  Service isnt great.  But, when was the last time you had great service at a real Chinese restaurant?  Good chinese food doesn't come with service, it's about speed and quality.  This is common sense

I've tried many Chinese restaurants in Vancouver, SF, Los Angeles, Beijing, and Taiwan - this ranks up there.  

Most importantly, their food feels like my family cooked it. It's classic Chinese food here. 

The people that rank this place below 4 stars are probably from the PF Chang and Panda Express crowd.  They dont have a developed tongue for true Chinese food.   Dont come here if you're one of those people that order those "classical normal" dishes -  Kong Pao Chicken, Sweet and Sour Chicken, Fried rice etc - stick to PF Chang and Panda Express.
author: Mike L.

description: Came here because Five Happiness was closed for construction today. We were seated immediately, but it took them forever to come take our order. We had Pork Dumplings, XiaoLong Bao, Spicy Seafood Noodles, Chow Mein, Beef Pancakes, and the Salt and Peppered Tofu. The wrap of the dumplings were too thick and hard for our likings so noone liked it. The Ma La spicy seafood noodles weren't flavorful aside from its spice, which was disappointing because I read in Yelp reviews that it was good. I think of all items we ordered, my family enjoyed the beef pancakes most. It was crunchy, with the perfect flavoring of beef and veggies to pair with. These are to be eat fresh and shouldnt be taken home to eat after, fyi. The chow mein wasn't the best i've ever had, but it was better than the dumplings too. I also dont think you can go wrong with salt and peppered tofu. A bit oily, but the crunchiness was good. Probably won't be back though.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Bring your fambam, friends, neighbors! etc. 

Just bring a big party because the food here is yummy, the portions are huge, and it's a shame to go with just 1 other person, as you can't order more plates of delicious food! 

Case in point, me and bf ordered the ribs stew soup with napa cabbage. It was brought out in a decent-sized wok over a charcoal warmer, pipping hot and beckoning to be devoured. We overstuffed ourselves, looked at the wok and it barely looked like anyone put a dent to it. We received a large plastic soup/noodle container to take home and to our surprise, there was sill soup leftover in the wok even after we filled the container to the RIM. We got a couple of good meals at home with rice afterwards.

We've ordered their xiao long bao, whole steamed fish, sizzling plate fish, sauteed pea sprouts, and everything is super flavorful and delicious. As for service, for a Chinese restaurant, they're actually not too bad! The server wished us to "take care and walk slow" as we left.

Don't let the name discourage you from trying this place. You'll be glad you did!
author: Jing D.

description: Dong Bei MAMA!  Just yell it out it pretty stress relieving.  This northern style Chinese was really good.  It tasted good going in but the next day it blew going out. Pwned.  I would definitely go back.  It was worth the stomachache.
author: Fatty A.

description: Came here for a late lunch with my dad, he recommended it because I was in the mood for some spicy noodles. He had the spicy seafood noodle soup. Had the right amount of kick without being too unbearable. You could really taste the Szechuan pepper corns. I had the dan dan mein. Oh my god, it was so good. You could really taste the garlic, basil and chili oil. The same noodles were used in both dishes yet in my dish it almost tasted better because it had that al dente bite to it. Can't say much for the rest of the menu at this time but I'd be willing to come back and try more sometime.
author: Sarah L.

description: spent years looking for spicy chinese food in SF. Finally found it a few years ago (and just now getting around to writing a review). *love* spicy beef noodle soup, beef in dry wok, spicy fish filet. spicy boiled beef is also a go to favorite.
author: Sandra K.

description:
In a city, where cantonese style Chinese cuisine rules supreme, it's difficult to find a Chinese restaurant that serves food of other regions.

I'm always on the prowl for good szechuan food, or good dongbei food. This location used to be Panda Country Restaurant, which was known for super authentic Chinese food. I dropped by due to good hearsay and found the restaurant to have changed hands.

Dongbei Mama's food was decent. The dishes that I ordered were spot on. But I wish they had more selections. Their menu seemed to match that of Old Islamic Restaurant. Regardless, I would come back. 

I was going to mention that portions were a bit small... but everyone else seem to think the portions big so maybe I eat too much.
author: Alice W.

description:
Another restaurant on Geary Street, but you're not going to want to miss this place.  Try if at all possible to come here with a big group of people to taste as many things as you can or just order a lot. 

What we ate:
Pickled cabbage and Pork sour soup-  Served in a wok looking bowl over a portable stove.  Comes with glass noodles and takes a hunk of space on your table.  (A hint of sourness perks your taste buds as you keep wanting to eat more.)

Beef pancake roll- Green onion pancake roulade with dried/cured beef, cilantro, and onions.  Sounds weird, but it was pretty good.  A must try.

Mapo Tofu- If you like it spicy, then ask for it.  Another delicious dish, worthy of not sharing.

Baked tofu with chives - As simple as it sounds, but if you don't like chives, steer away from this and maybe get a mixed veggie dish.

In summary this is good regional Chinese food.  I liked it and maybe you will too.  So put on your shoes, call up your buddies and order up!

Decor: 3
Food:4
Service: 3 (They try)

Would I go back? You bet your pastrami I would!
author: Kelson H.

description:
I've been here twice in the past few weeks with my family who recently discovered it and liked it.  The restaurant is somewhat clean, perhaps because it's still a little new and you probably don't have to wait for a table at all.  

The food is actually not bad.  I've tried the beef wrap, an assortment of dumplings, which are both good.  The beef noodle soup is actually my favorite that I've had here.  Beef stew makes anything taste good and the broth is a little salty, but not overboard.  The spicy seafood soup with the hot oil is also tasty.  I did choke twice drinking the spicy soup because it does have a kick to it, but it's not so spicy that I can't take it.

The service here is awful.  I don't know if they just don't understand English or what.  Depends what server you get.  One woman I asked for a straw.  She said okay and I watched her wander into the little kitchen area, slowly walk around in circles and never came back.  I think she knew I was watching her too.  She just completely ignored us after that.  On the same visit, I asked a waiter for a fork and a knife.  He nodded.  He got the fork right, but he brought out an entire container of sugar... Huh???  We thus resorted to using hand motions and showing the guy how to cut with our imaginary knife that he did not give us.  Ahh.  finally he gets it.

When it came to the check, they just kept passing by our table and we had to try to flag them down several times just to get the check.  A nice waitress gave us boxes and actually started boxing up the dumplings for us.  Then she took off.  Well she gets the easy part and we get to pour all the soup into the containers to take home.  It's okay though.  She tried.  

I'm sure I'll be back since the family likes the food, but next time I'll be prepared to get whatever I want from the kitchen by myself.
author: Stacey C.

description: Came here on a Saturday night for dinner for 2 and was seated promptly. The menu is pretty expansive and this place would be good for a large dinner party, given the variety of large family style dishes and the large tables. We ordered the beef roll pancake, which had a nice cucumber filling, the dry fried chicken, which was very ma la, and the twice cooked pork, which was okay. I might come here with a larger group next time to try more dishes. Overall an okay meal though.
author: J L.

description:
Definitely not the place to for north eastern chinese food.  The shanghai dumplings were the frozen kind and were not close to mimicking Kingdom of Dumpling's frozen dumplings.  The skin would just deteriorate and was very soggy.  The green onion pancake was good but the ones from Little Beijing blows it out of the water.  The hot and sour with pork noodle soup was way too salty.  Try going to Taiwan (restaurant) for that.  These are the bare standards of north eastern chinese food and it simply does not cut it if they can't excel at any one of them.

Bottom line: Look elsewhere.
author: Allen T.

description:
we came here on a friday night with some friends who love this restaurant.  this seems like a family owned place with multiple generations working here.  they serve northern chinese food. 

we had the bean sheet noodle salad.  i loved it!  also the soup was good.  we requested everything with no msg and i didnt get an allergic reaction and the food was still yummy.  we also had noodles, string beans,  and fish head.  my friends did all the ordering so im not sure of the official menu names of the dishes.  

yum
author: claudia y.

description:
I had some hot pot soup here, baby bok choy and tofu that blew my mind. So flavorful and the tofu was the perfect texture. Had some dumplings and pancake as well which were pretty good. 

Service was pretty decent- they were very friendly but a bit slow for how empty the restaurant was. I will definitely be back for that soup.
author: Madeline C.

description: I came here because a friend had a great experience. The place was your typical Asian Mom/Pop restaurant. I had great expectation after reading most of the reviews. We had Westlake soup, it was pretty good. Within 3 minutes of our main course arrived, this is so typical. We had order peas-sprout sautéed with garlic, it was bland. The Green Onion Cakes was really bad, I was looking for the green onion all I got was flours. My daughter can make better cakes. Next Spicy Sparerib it was okay, I found it bland wish it had more spices. I had complain about the onion cakes not being tasty, all I got back from the server was "sorry". The rave reviews was duds for me. Disappointing.
author: Kim B.

description: My husband and I love this place! We always get the spicy beef in flaming oil, and spicy chicken wings. The food is so authentic and never disappointing . I also have to say I love the young waitress who is always so nice and pleasant.
author: Em C.

description:
yum! so glad this place exists in the RIchmond. It's hard to find a great chinese place in SF, believe it or not.

Favorites:
*spicy chicken wings
* beef pancake roll (with chives anc cilantro)
*black pepper fish cooked in clay pot

Everything is seriously yummy and not greasy like other places. Service has definitely improved from the earlier reviews.
author: Natasha F.

description: Was itching for some unique, China village style cooking and found it at Dong Bei Mama. An assortment of high-carb dumblings and baked goods like the beef pancakes / cakes really hit the spot. Throw in an assortment of bubbling stews and very traditional plates and you got yourself a culinary trip to mainland China by driving to the Richmond. This is the spot for Asian comfort food on a chilly night..
author: Ed L.

description: This is a cute place to eat family style . Hot pot is super good definitely recommend to order slice beef pancake ! The prices are affordable and I would recommend those who are on a budget come here ! :)
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Definitely . We were suppose to go to Dim Sum at HK Lounge, but there were too many people so we tried Mayflower, which was less, but still crowded. So settled here. Ordered 5 things totaling $30 which is SUPER cheap, however, taste wise, not that impressed.

We got a spicy seafood noodle soup (ma-la), sparerib noodle soup, xiaolongbao, sesame cake, and soymilk and fried ghost. The only thing that I enjoyed was probably the Spicy Seafood Noodle Soup, mainly because it brought me back to Shanghai where I could find ma-la everywhere. Other than that, the Sparerib noodle soup was eh, the xiaolongbao was oversteamed, causing the skin to break, the sesame cake was kinda bland for me, and the soy milk was way too sweet. 

2 stars. It wasn't painful, but honestly, eh.

Btws, limited cantonese here. Most of the people we dealt with spoke Mandarin. And D's mother proclaims that theres a similar place down the street that was much better.
author: Jessica H.

description: really liked the bean noodles. Tried the pork and sauerkraut and enjoyed it.
author: Xing L.

description:
The portions here are large, cheap, and decent tasting.  The beef pancake roll was pretty good, but I will say the insides of it with cucumber, chives, and cilantro was not necessary and the beef roll could have just been made with the beef and the flaky/chewy bread wrapping.  We also ordered the spicy catfish with tofu and beef chow fun and those tasted fresh and were very large portioned.

We had a group of 3 and basically came out to $12/person and we were stuffed and had leftovers from the meal.

The loss of one star is the waiting staff.  They weren't as attentive as they could have been.

Overall, I would recommend coming back as they are one of the better Chinese restaurants in the city.
author: Lawrence E.

description:
Yumm, I think I may still be dreaming about that beef pancake 2 days later.

Fairly spacious, with attentive and quick staff.

I love when friends know what to order, so here's our list:
++ Sliced Beef pancake: Built like a swiss roll, but instead of cake= crispy Chinese pancake; instead of cream/jelly= chunks of beef and fresh veggies. (~6 pcs for one roll)
++ cumin lamb in iron platter: yes, as good as it sounds
+ Braised pork yam noodle: I could eat the silver flat noodles all day
+ Green pepper potato: firm and tasty
+Dry wok fish: good portion, but SWIMMING in chili oil

+ typical, and enjoyable: Spareribs w/ garlic; mixed veg.; sauteed green beans

The only complaint is that everything had a bit more oil than expected, but we finished everything nonetheless!

Tip: chinese donut & soy milk only on Saturdays
author: Angel L.

description: Delicious food, great service, great price! Bring your appetite because the portions are HUGE. I'm definitely coming back to eat here again! :)
author: Zoë B.

description: I decided to go to this restaurant because a friend of mine said that it got some really great reviews but I unfortunately was disappointed. It did not live up to the hype. The food tasted about average for a Chinese place and there wasn't anything in particular that blew me away. I must admit that the beef cake was really good. The pancake was crispy and moist, the beef was well cooked, and the vegetables in the dish were fresh and flavorful. I really enjoyed that one dish... The rest of the dishes we got left me wanting more. I'd say for a Chinese restaurant it rates at a two.... Because I've been to some really great Chinese restaurants, especially in this area. Service was fine and price was fine. The only reasons that I'd come back to this restaurant is for the beef cake.
author: William N.

description:
The style is Szechuan / Hunan which are spicy, greazy dishes. If that's what you want then this is the place. Otherwise, go elsewhere.

A lot of people write bad reviews for places on Yelp because they don't know what they want, thus don't know where they end up.
author: Randy L.

description: Everything was fantastic - highly recommend the sweet and sour chicken, hot and sour soup and potstickers. So happy we found this place!
author: Shannon S.

description:
I honestly love the food here. I crave it often. The food is tasty, cheap, and the restaurant itself is pretty clean. 

I give it the four stars because the service is so-so. 

LOVE: the pig ear, crispy pork intestines, lamb hot pot with napa cabbage, and tea infused spareribs.

also notable are the bean sheets and enoki mushrooms. 

my least favorite is the beef tendon simply because there was too much beef and not enough tendon. but still good! 
I want to try everything here.

As for service, it is close to impossible to get their attention when they are super busy.  And even when I did get their attention, (for instance I straight up stared deeply into this woman's eyes) and she straight up ignored me. AND I asked for waterS and she gave me only one glass, leaving my bf with a numbing tongue. 

Still I would recommend going to this place if you like the numbing feeling on your tongue and love Chinese food.
author: Stephanie T.

description: Chinese restaurants can be such a gamble that finding a place with service like Dong Bei Mama's can feel like taking a refreshing sip of water. The staff was very accommodating, offering helpful suggestions for my specialized diet (I keep kashrut during the High Holidays) and checking in on me without being terribly obtrusive. I ordered the lamb with cumin, which came in ample portions though it didn't light my world on fire taste-wise. I could definitely sense the MSG on the plate, and probably should've opted for something a bit lighter, but them's the breaks. Overall I would recommend it. In fact, I plan to return again and try the Szechuan menu and see if that raises my opinion.
author: Tory A.

description: Had some work at Geary street, and was hungry. Went to this restaurant without reading any reviews or opinions. I was surprised to find the restaurant was very clean and nicely decorated. I ordered kung-pao chicken and my wife ordered tofu fried rice. The food was amazingly good. Portion size was amazingly large. Not only i finished whole kung pao chicken but was very happy with it. The staff was polite and courteous. I will definitely go here to eat if I go in the area. Wonderful Chinese Food.  Not expensive either.
author: Rockin R.

description:
The sliced beef pancake was one of the best things I have eaten in a long time.  I would go there again just to eat an order all by myself.

Everything else was also very good and I would certainly go back again.
author: Leo S.

description: This isn't a must visit, but if you do, you'll be rewarded with delicious food to enjoy. I especially liked the beef pancake.
author: David O.

description: This place is nasty. Before I could eat 2 bites the waiter walked by, and without covering his mouth or turning away, sneezed right onto me and my food, then walked over to an empty table and sneezed all over it. I don't expect a Chinese restaurant to be the cleanest, but feeling a waiter sneeze on my face, not cool..
author: Alison L.

description: I think the reviews were kinda misleading. Food were bad. I order pick up sometimes. The food were always cold and dry. Not even tasty. I won't come here anymore.
author: Jamie A.

description:
WOW, summer time and this place is packed with tourist. Especially those from mandarin native speaking areas. (This place is known for its mandarin specialties) 

After waiting 10 minutes in line, we was pretty hungry. We ordered their specialty "Lamb pot" or whatever thats called. Wow that tasted awesome, would've been better if it was winter. Food is on point, service was great. Although food took a while, it was worth the wait.

Hot food all the way here, its sort of like a hot pot. However, they give you a stove for every individual side. Although it might look appealing, come inside and order 1 dish. It'll fill you up for sure.
author: Jared Z.

description: So sad to see restaurants that ive been going to are cutting down food portion. This place is one of them. Or maybe they changed the chief?
author: Sam W.

description:
I'm really surprised this restaurant doesn't have more customers. I hope more people in San Francisco develop the palate for this type of Chinese food, instead of letting South Bay have all the great non-Cantonese Chinese food. 

This place serves good Northern Chinese cuisine and it's my go-to restaurant in San Francisco when I have a Chinese food craving. They serve different dishes than San Tung does (another Northern Chinese joint on Irving) and obviously completely different dishes than your typical Cantonese restaurant does.

There are three dishes that I highly recommend. But I don't know their English names because typically my parents order the dishes, so I'll just describe the dishes with a mix of the Mandarin names and my English translation. Hopefully you can communicate it to the waiter:

Niu Rou Juan Bing (Beef twisted pancake) - awesome appetizer, with beef, green onions, wrapped in a Chinese pancake

Yang Rou Xiao Cao (Lamb stir fry) - lamb cooked with some vegetables on an iron plate 

I can't remember the Chinese name for this, but this is a seafood hot pot soup that comes to your table in a wok with a live flame underneath. This soup is so money. The broth is light but very tasty, comes with clear noodles and a seafood medley. Best thing to have on a cold day.

Patronize this restaurant! It's seriously a loss for SF Chinese restaurant scene if this place closes down.
author: nate c.

description: Everything is so delicious and they just the same flavor as my home town!! Highly recommend for northeastern Chinese!
author: Xiao C.

description: Authentic family style Chinese food. Huge portions of tasty food. I'm not a fan of the salty dumplings with their sauce (heavy on the vinegar), but really enjoyed their braised fish, salt and pepper fish, sautéed green beans, and sliced beef pancake.
author: C B.

description: Awesome food. Large portions and cheap price. Very authentic Dong Bei Cuisine!
author: Zhen W.

description: Left perfectly satisfied after an all veg meal. Hot-n-sour soup was the best.
author: J B.

description: Very big portions and really delicious.  They've got this one dish that comes out in a metal stove with a little fire underneath.  I forgot what it is called but it has pork blood, intestines, tofu and a little spicy.  VERY FREAKING GOOD!  The best I've tasted so far.
author: Eric C.

description: We were hungry and wanted some Asian food that was close to where we were staying. Eyes were big and stomach was empty so we ordered a lot of food. It was funny because our server was laughing when we told him everything we wanted to order. He told us "you are ordering too much!!" I think the cook didn't want to cook it all. Ha! Food was good...even though I wasn't feeling the beefcake.
author: Kristie F.

description: The large immigration influx from Mainland China has provided a greater diversity of Chinese food available to SF.  There menu is large... Too extensive if you ask me.  Stick with the Northern style food that they specialize.  Avoid dumplings and xiao long bao.  They are clueless when it comes to how dumplings should be prepared.
author: Laurence H.

description: This place is legit.  I'm a fan of all Chinese food, but this place is better than most.  I veered from my normal order and tried some different things - black pepper fish clay pot and dau lo soup.  Both were very good.  As with most Chinese places, go with others so you can order a lot and eat different things.  Or just be prepared to take a lot home with you.  Highly recommend!
author: Jonathan D.

description: Their beef pancake roll and beef cake are the best! Everything else taste pretty good, too, but these two dishes are their highlight. I only wish they kept their restrooms a bit cleaner :p
author: Candy L.

description:
pros: 
dishes are actually spicy
service was good for a chinese restaurant, especially from a rural region

cons: 
prices are steep

the most disappointing item we ordered was the sesame chicken, which was basically sweet and sour chicken...it was mostly batter. if i wanted sesame fried corn starch i would've ordered that no? grrr, bugs me every time!

on a happier note, their pig's head appetizer dish was delicious if you like cartilage in your meat. nicely seasoned and a decent portion.
author: Melissa Y.

description: I was hoping to give them a good review.  The service was not good bec you can never get their attention and it seemed like they had no experience. The food was not very good either except maybe the hot and sour soup.
author: Mary L.

description:
finally a worth-going chinese restaurent.

this place is great. good price, good portion, great menu and great service.

we went there for lunch and we had 4 dishes for 33 dollars.. and we couldn't even finish a half of them. i had to take home 5 containers of food.. they were all delicious and well prepared. 

we didn't get to try the beef pancake roll but we tried their pig ear appetizer, lamb hot pot, pork and napa dumplings and fried pork. 

i would not hesitate to take my chinese food-goer friends here. i am feeling just so satisfied. :)
author: Sung C.

description: Tried out this place for my father's birthday. My family esp my father didnt care too much on how the food tasted.   service was alright.  was expecting a lot more from what i read about dong bei mama.  probably won't go back
author: Kenton C.

description: Wanted to like this place given my perennial search for good Chinese (non canto) food in SF.  Pretty disappointed.  First of all, I love Northern Chinese.  Guess my expectations were too high.  I was expecting similar quality to what exists in so cal.  Not the case.  The beef wrapped in pancake and tea smoked duck were both let downs.  Doubt I would go back.
author: Eric C.

description: Interesting experience. We were the only caucasians  in the restaurant. Very family, no frills, Chinese food. I would love to come back and really learn the menu. I think I would learn a lot about Chinese food. Sadly, we were only tourists and had a tough time ordering. Helpings were generous and well-prepared.
author: FromScratch M.

description: Definitely not Cantonese.  Mostly northern & Sichuan dishes.  Very interesting menu but need to go back with a big group to explore unique dishes.  1st visit, beef pancake was outstanding.
author: Mario S.

description: I liked it. I ordered this noodle dish. I like soba noodles. But having buckwheat noodles kills the taste of the sauce. I like all the dishes we ordered. I didn't like the customer service that much though.
author: M L.

description:
Had one of the best meals of my life here a couple of weeks ago.  Which is saying a lot for me .  I really was in heaven.

Decided to try the Chongqing Fish - delicious super-fresh pieces of fish deep-fried in batter and spiced up with chilis and Sichuan peppers. Just perfect.  Then the Fish a la Szechuan, just delicious, as noted before.  Dipped the Chongqing pieces of fish into the sauce - wow.  And mopped up the rest with their excellent green onion pancakes.

I'm still going back here regularly.  The inconsistency seems to have gone.  Just fantastic depth of flavor in their Sichuan dishes.
author: Ritch G.

description: Must order the beef pancake roll... So good. The food is good, cheap, and very authentic. Once you open the doors of this great restaurant, you'll noticed that it's packed with...Chinese People!... Wow, a Chinese restaurant packed with Chinese people, it must be a very good place.
author: kelly t.

description: In general, very traditional/original flavor of Northern style Chinese food. The sour cabbage, and lamb dishes are pretty good. Tried some of their Shichuan flavor dishes, not that spicy, at least not to my standard.
author: Lydia L.

description: The pancake is worth the trip alone. Lots of preserved type / northern chinese dishes. Really great.
author: Mark R.

description: came here around 9:30pm which i know sucks cause they close at 10pm. We were respectable at didn't leave too late. left at 10:05pm. food wasn't too good at that time. I did however enjoyed the crispy intestines. it was a good bar food type dish. we got the eggplant, some noodle soup thing, dumplings, intestines, and some white rice. wasn't great but i think i'd consider going back another time when its not close to closing. i did like their customer service. super nice to us.
author: Josephine S.

description: I came in here wasn't expecting anything spectacular because I'm not too big of a Chinese food fan. But I must say I was wrong. Not only are they delicious, their food was different. Different meaning I have never tried this type of Chinese food!!  When I think about Chinese food, I think about orange chicken or sweet and sour chicken. But not here, they have items I have never ever seen In my life. So I decided to order random item on the menu crossing my finger hoping it might turn out good. So I order this pork belly napa cabbage in a soup boil pot, ma po tofu, beef sandwich, and one more but I forgot the name of it. Not only were they good they were delicious. I was amazed how much I have love their food. And now that's one if my favorite spot to eat at. The pork belly napa cabbage is my boyfriend favorite. I really enjoy eating the ma po tofu. It spicy n flavorful!! We both love the beef sandwich it is very original. They do serve a very big portion so it better to go with a big group so you can try all the item.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Love this place!  Decided to have chinese at some place other than our weekly trip to Potsticker King, lo and behold - Dong Bei Mama!   

We noticed it while cruising on Geary looking for a new place to have dinner.  As much as I hate to admit, yelpers were right with the beef pancake.  It's probably the best I've ever had.  And if you're a fan of spicy pig ear, this is the place to get it.  

Though, I still prefer Potsticker King's Chong Ching Chicken, this place is pretty kick-ass.  I many take-outs in the future with this place.
author: John C.

description: solid 5 stars for the food.  it is northeastern chinese foods.  the seafood noodle soup  and their spicy beef hot pot is super flavorful and delicious.  it is so good.  wished they had one in boston.
author: Momo K.

description: First, let me defend the service. I believe that some of the fellow Yelpers got stiffed, but speaking strictly for myself, I was totally happy with all 3 waitresses which at some point or other graced our table with their presence. There is also a dude there; maybe he ruffled someone's feathers, but since he rendered us neither service, not disservice, will presume him innocent as well. Now, the food. Pig Head appetizer was indeed very good (as was observed by others), lamb pot with cabbage - pretty sure it is the way it should be (somewhat like Russian "schi" - sour cabbage borscht), it's just that I do not personally care for it (which is not a reason to knock off any stars). Beef Shao Bing was good, too - more flavour than in many other places, and more of it than in many other places. So, children,  I do recommend you go to Mama.
author: Alex T.

description: Dry fried green beans were the bomb, five spice spicy and tender but crunchy. Loved the szechuan chicken wings, fried niblets with that citrusy anaesthetic pepper  that'll heat up your howdy. The szechuan fish and tofu was a family size dish of soft white fish and silky tofu coated in a peppery red sauce. The spicy eggplant was chunks of asian eggplant, red peppers, onion and garlic in a chili-hoisin sauce. We tried the beef green onion pancake and it was served like a savory jellyroll, sliced in finger food sized rolls, ready to pick up and bite. Stuffed with cilantro and beef, thay are a good appetizer for a group, left us with a week's worth of lunches. The portions are large and prices are low for the  quality. Service was fast and attentive. At the back of the restaurant is a refrigerated case of special delicacies like pig's ear and beef stomach. Next time we'll order off the chinese menu and try the regional salads. Hubby can't wait to go back!
author: Kelly K.

description: good dumplings, authentic northern chinese food
author: felicia s.

description: The food is pretty good. The service is decent IF there are no tour groups around. It's best to go there after 7:00 pm so you can avoid all the Chinese tour groups and get a good service.
author: shan t.

description:
um.... ew.
why this place has four stars i don't know.

When we arrived, there was a good amount of people in there.
The sticky plates and dirty utensils should have been a clue to the quality of this place, but there were a lot of people in there and i had already walked more than 15 blocks in heels.  

Maybe cuz i didn't know how to order, but if they weren't going to make everything good, they should take some dishes off the menu.
ordered the crispy lamb and fish in spicy stew.

the waiters were nice but the food was just disgusting.
both dishes came out still cold and there was a thick layer of chili oil in the fish dish.
the fish was just some cheap, frozen filet that had probably been in the freezer for at least a year.  lamb had a lot of cumin, but was salty and chewy. it also had a lot of fat and other weird stuff.
I was just looking for something edible.  when i walk into a restaurant, i don't expect a lot.  i think this is probably one of the worst establishments i've ever been to.  I've been to a lot of terrible restaurants, but it was the first time i'd been to one that served vomit-inducing "food"

it was also expensive.  ~$35-40 for the two dishes and some undercooked rice.  

i hate when i waste money on disgusting food.
author: Candy Y.

description: shanghai chinese food, which is very different than regular chinese food. flavors are more sweet and spicy, its not really my taste. the dessert wasnt so good..
author: kim w.

description:
I suggested this restaurant to my mom and grandpa after the great reviews I read, however this place was a huge disappointment.  We went in around 12:30pm on a Monday and there were only two other tables.  We ordered their Dong Bei styled chicken, steamed cod (or of that sort), and bok choy with mushrooms.  The fish was the best dish out of the three, but that's no compliment because all the other Chinese restaurants I've been to are better.  The sauce on the mushroom and bok choy dish was way to salty/heavy despite the steamed bok choy.  The chicken dish was horrible, there were parts of the chicken that were hard to chew and the whole dish was so bland that I had to add salt.  Now for the worst part: the rice was too hard/stale!  I know a lot of the rice in restaurants are towards the hard side, but this was really bad.  My mom, who has a sensitive stomach, later felt ill due to the hard rice and my stomach, which has an impressive digestive system, felt a little discomfort as well.  

Needless to say, I will never come back here again...  There are plenty of other authentic Chinese restaurants out there in the Sunset area.

Note: Right after we sat down, a group of tourists came in a flurry.  It seems that the restaurant has a deal with the tourism company to have lunch here because food was brought out to them immediately.  They were loud and someone at one point was smoking (wtf?!).
author: Joy Z.

description: love this place. This place is a crouching tiger, hidden dragon in sf. We have ween for many times already and we enjoyed each visit there. Great food, great price, great amount of food. I suggest going out to eat with a group of people so every one can share all the dishes. order the lamb soup, the best!
author: Ella T.

description: I love this place. I go there whenever I'm craving simple homey Chinese food. I love the beef with noodles and the mapo tofu. The free unlimited tea is nice, and the hundreds of Chinese tourists bussed in gives it a great atmosphere.
author: Sarah B.

description: Awesome food, ok service.  I have tried many chinese restaurants in the city, and this one have some of the best mainland food (assuming you like authentic not-americanized Chinese food).  The restaurant used to be a Si Chuan food restaurant, and the food was even better then.  Now their menus are more extensive and they put all their si chuan food on the last page of the menu - that's where I go.
author: J. B.

description: This place just opened and I approve. Quality food, vegetarian items. Their cooking style sets them apart, it's not the typical Americanized Chinese place.  They serve authentic regional dishes with their own style. I like their shredded potato dish.
author: David F.
